characters: B-47 PARKING SPACE ADJOINING GLENDALE STATION
NEFF'S FACE LOW DOWN IN THE CORNER BEHIND
E-1 WITNESS ROOM IN DEATH CHAMBER
C-8 NEFF ON TELEPHONE IN HIS APARTMENT
B-2 A BOARD OF CHINESE CHECKERS CAMERA WITHDRAWS AND
D-19 HALL STAIRWAY OF DIETRICHSON HOME, (NIGHT)
D-8 TELEPHONE BOOTH IN JERRY'S MARKET
THE CAMERA SLOWLY BEGINS TO MOVE IN AND DOWN, AND CENTERS
CAMERA PULLS BACK WITH HER INTO THE LIVING ROOM.
D-10 SHELVES IN THE REAR OF MARKET
A-26 STAIRCASE, (FROM NEFF'S POINT OF VIEW)
GRADUALLY REVEALS THE DIETRICHSON LIVING ROOM
E-12 CORRIDOR OUTSIDE THE DEATH CHAMBER
A-16 SHOOTING DOWN FROM UPPER LANDING
E-3 THE DOOR TO THE GAS CHAMBER
B-70 DARK STREET NEAR NEFF'S APT. HOUSE
B-13 ROWS OF HIGH SHELVES IN MARKET
A-9 THE ELEVENTH FLOOR FROM ABOVE

dialogues.speaker: A-1 LOS ANGELES
dialogues.text: It is night, about two o'clock, very light traffic. At the left and in the immediate foreground a semaphore  traffic signal stands at GO. Approaching it at about thir miles per hour is a Dodge 1938 coupe. It is driven errati and weaving a little, but not out of control. When the car is about forty feet away, the signal changes STOP. Car makes no attempt to stop but comes on through.

dialogues.speaker: A-2 A LIGHT NEWSPAPER TRUCK
dialogues.text: is crossing the intersection at right angles. It swerves skids to avoid the Dodge, which goes on as though nothing had happened. The truck stops with a panicky screech of t There is a large sign on the truck: "READ THE LOS ANGELES TIMES". The truck driver's infuriated face stares after t coupe.

dialogues.speaker: A-3 THE COUPE
dialogues.text: continues along the street, still weaving, then slows dow and pulls over towards the curb in front of a tall office building.

dialogues.speaker: A-4 THE COUPE
dialogues.text: stops. The headlights are turned off. For a second nothin happens, then the car door opens slowly. A man eases hims out onto the sidewalk and stands a moment leaning on the  open door to support himself. He's a tall man, about thir five years old. From the way he moves there seems to be  something wrong with his left shoulder. He straightens up and painfully lowers his left hand into his jacket pocket. He leans into the car. He brings out a light-weight overcoat and drapes it across his shoulders. shuts the car door and walks toward the building.

dialogues.speaker: A-5 ENTRANCE OF THE BUILDING
dialogues.text: Above the closed, double-plate glass doors is lettered:  "PACIFIC BUILDING". To the left of entrance there is a  drugstore, closed, dark except for a faint light in the b The man comes stiffly up to the doors. (CAMERA HAS MOVED WITH HIM). He tries the doors. They are locked. He knocks the glass. Inside, over his shoulder, the lobby of the  building is visible: a side entrance to the drugstore on left, in the rear a barber shop and cigar and magazine st closed up for the night, and to the right two elevators. elevator is open and its dome light falls across the dark lobby. The man knocks again. The night watchman sticks his head of the elevator and looks toward entrance. He comes out w a newspaper in one hand and a half-eaten sandwich in the  other. He finishes the sandwich on the way to the doors,  looks out and recognizes the man outside, unlocks the doo and pulls it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello there, Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff walks in past him without answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff is walking towards elevator. Night watchman looks af him, relocks door, follows to elevator. Neff enters eleva

dialogues.speaker: A-7 ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Neff stands leaning against wall. He is pale and haggard  with pain, but deadpans as night watchman joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working pretty late aren't you, Mr.  Neff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Tight-lipped) Late enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look kind of all in at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Let's ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night watchman pulls lever, doors close and elevator rise

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the insurance business, Mr.  Neff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wouldn't ever sell me any. They  say I've got something loose in my  heart. I say it's rheumatism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Scarcely listening) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night watchman looks around at him, turns away again and elevator stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Surly) Twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Across a small dark reception room a pair frosted glass doors are lettered: PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURA COMPANY - FOUNDED 1906 - MAIN OFFICE. There is a little l beyond the glass doors. Neff straightens up and walks heavily out of the elevator across reception room to doors. He pushes them open. The  night watchman stares after him morosely, works lever,  elevator doors start to close.

dialogues.speaker: A-8 TWELFTH FLOOR INSURANCE OFFICE
dialogues.text: (Note for set-designer: Our Insurance Company occupies th entire eleventh and twelfth floors of the building. On th twelfth floor are the executive offices and claims and sa departments. These all open off a balcony which runs all way around. From the balcony you see the eleventh floor b one enormous room filled with desks, typewriters, filing  cabinets, business machines, etc.) Neff comes through the double entrance doors from the  reception room. The twelfth floor is dark. Some light shi up from the eleventh floor. Neff takes a few steps then h on to the balcony railing and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: A-9 THE ELEVENTH FLOOR FROM ABOVE
dialogues.text: Two colored women are cleaning the offices. One is dry-mo the floor, the other is moving chairs back into position, etc. A colored man is emptying waste baskets into a big s box. He shuffles a little dance step as he moves, and hum little tune.

dialogues.speaker: A-10 NEFF
dialogues.text: Moves away from the railing with a faint smile on his fac and walks past two or three offices (CAMERA WITH HIM) tow a glass door with number twenty-seven on it and three nam HENRY B. ANDERSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. SCHWARTZ. Neff o the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three desks, filing cabinets, one typewriter on stand, on dictaphone on fixed stand against wall with rack of recor underneath, telephones on all three desks. Water cooler w inverted bottle and paper cup holder beside it. Two windo facing toward front of building. Venetian blinds. No curt Waste basket full, ash trays not emptied. The office has been cleaned. Neff enters, switches on desk lamp. He looks across at di phone, goes heavily to it and lifts off the fabric cover. leans down hard on the dictaphone stand as if feeling fai He turns away from dictaphone, takes a few uncertain step and falls heavily into a swivel chair. His head goes far  back, his eyes close, cold sweat shows on his face. For a moment he stays like this, exhausted, then his eyes open  slowly and look down at his left shoulder. His good hand  flips the overcoat back, he unbuttons his jacket, loosens his tie and shirt. This was quite an effort. He rests for second, breathing hard. With the help of his good hand he edges his left elbow up on the arm-rest of the chair, sup it there and then pulls his jacket wide. A heavy patch of dark blood shows on his shirt. He pushes his chair along floor towards the water cooler, using his feet and his ri hand against the desk, takes out a handkerchief, presses  with his hand against the spring faucet of the cooler, so the handkerchief in water and tucks it, dripping wet, aga the wound inside his shirt. Next, he gets a handful of wa and splashes it on his face. The water runs down his chin and drips. He breathes heavily, with closed eyes. He fing a pack of cigarettes in his shirt pocket, pulls it out, l at it. There is blood on it. He wheels himself back to th desk and dumps the loose cigarettes out of the packet. So are blood-stained, a few are clean. He takes one, puts it between his lips, gropes around for a match, lights cigar He takes a deep drag and lets smoke out through his nose. He pulls himself toward dictaphone again, still in the sw chair, reaches it, lifts the horn off the bracket and the dictaphone makes a low buzzing sound. He presses the butt switch on the horn. The sound stops, the record revolves the cylinder. He begins to speak:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Office memorandum, Walter Neff to  Barton Keyes, Claims Manager. Los  Angeles, July 16th, 1938. Dear Keyes:  I suppose you'll call this a  confession when you hear it. I don't  like the word confession. I just  want to set you right about one thing  you couldn't see, because it was  smack up against your nose. You think  you're such a hot potato as a claims  manager, such a wolf on a phoney  claim. Well, maybe you are, Keyes,  but let's take a look at this  Dietrichson claim, Accident and Double  Indemnity. You were pretty good in  there for a while, all right. You  said it wasn't an accident. Check.  You said it wasn't suicide. Check.  You said it was murder. Check and  double check. You thought you had it  cold, all wrapped up in tissue paper,  with pink ribbons around it. It was  perfect, except that it wasn't,  because you made a mistake, just one  tiny little mistake. When it came to  picking the killer, you picked the  wrong guy, if you know what I mean.  Want to know who killed Dietrichson?  Hold tight to that cheap cigar of  yours, Keyes. I killed Dietrichson.  Me, Walter Neff, insurance agent, 35  years old, unmarried, no visible  scars -- (He glances down at  his wounded shoulder) Until a little while ago, that is.  Yes, I killed him. I killed him for  money -- and a woman -- and I didn't  get the money and I didn't get the  woman. Pretty, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He interrupts the dictation, lays down the horn on the de He takes his lighted cigarette from the ash tray, puffs i two or three times, and kills it. He picks up the horn ag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (His voice is now  quiet and contained) It began last May. About the end of  May, it was. I had to run out to  Glendale to deliver a policy on some  dairy trucks. On the way back I  remembered this auto renewal on Los  Feliz. So I decided to run over there.  It was one of those Calif. Spanish  houses everyone was nuts about 10 or  15 years ago. This one must have  cost somebody about 30,000 bucks --  that is, if he ever finished paying  for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he goes on speaking, SLOW DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: A-12 DIETRICHSON HOME
dialogues.text: Palm trees line the street, middle-class houses, mostly i Spanish style. Some kids throwing a baseball back and for across a couple of front lawns. An ice cream wagon dawdle along the block. Neff's coupe meets and passes the ice cr wagon and stops before one of the Spanish houses. Neff ge out. He carries a briefcase, his hat is a little on the b of his head. His movements are easy and full of ginger. H inspects the house, checks the number, goes up on the fro porch and rings the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was mid-afternoon, and it's funny,  I can still remember the smell of  honeysuckle all along that block. I  felt like a million. There was no  way in all this world I could have  known that murder sometimes can smell  like honeysuckle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff rings the bell again and waits. The door opens. A ma about forty-five, rather slatternly, opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dietrichson in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wants to see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name is Neff. Walter Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're selling something --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's Mr. Dietrichson I'd like  to talk to, and it's not magazine  subscriptions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes past her into the house.

dialogues.speaker: A-14 HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Spanish craperoo in style, as is the house throughout. A  wrought-iron staircase curves down from the second floor. fringed Mexican shawl hangs down over the landing. A larg tapestry hangs on the wall. Downstairs, the dining room t one side, living room on the other side visible through a wide archway. All of this, architecture, furniture,  decorations, etc., is genuine early Leo Carrillo period.  Neff has edged his way in past maid who still holds the d open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Mr. Dietrichson's not in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How soon do you expect him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be home when he gets here, if  that's any help to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point a voice comes from the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Nettie? Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff looks up.

dialogues.speaker: A-15 UPPER LANDING OF STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: Phyllis Dietrichson stands looking down. She is in her ea thirties. She holds a large bath-towel around her very  appetizing torso, down to about two inches above her knee She wears no stockings, no nothing. On her feet a pair of high-heeled bedroom slippers with pom-poms. On her left a a gold anklet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for Mr. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking down at Neff) I'm Mrs. Dietrichson. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: A-16 SHOOTING DOWN FROM UPPER LANDING
dialogues.text: Neff looks up, takes his hat off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Mrs. Dietrichson. I'm  Walter Neff, Pacific All-Risk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pacific all-what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pacific All-Risk Insurance Company.  It's about some renewals on the  automobiles, Mrs. Dietrichson. I've  been trying to contact your husband  for the past two weeks. He's never  at his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The insurance ran out on the  fifteenth. I'd hate to think of your  getting a smashed fender or something  while you're not fully covered.

dialogues.speaker: A-21 PHYLLIS
dialogues.text: She glances over her towel costume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With a little smile) Perhaps I know what you mean, Mr.  Neff. I've just been taking a sun  bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No pigeons around, I hope... About  those policies, Mrs. Dietrichson --  I hate to take up your time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. If you can wait  till I put something on, I'll be  right down. Nettie, show Mr. Neff  into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns away as gracefully as one can with a towel for wrapper.]

dialogues.speaker: A-24 ENTRANCE HALL
dialogues.text: Neff watches Phyllis out of sight. He speaks to the maid  while still looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would the living room be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In there, but they keep the liquor  locked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. I always carry my own  keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes through the archway. Maid goes off the other way.

dialogues.speaker: A-25 LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Neff comes into the room and throws his briefcase on the  plush davenport and tosses his hat on top of it. He looks around the room, then moves over to a baby grand piano wi a sleazy Spanish shawl dangling down one side and two cab photographs standing in a staggered position on top. Neff glances them over: Mr. Dietrichson, age about fifty-one, big, blocky man with glasses and a Rotarian look about hi Lola Dietrichson, age nineteen, wearing a filmy party dre and a yearning look in her pretty eyes. Neff walks away f the piano and takes a few steps back and forth across the rug. His eyes fall on a wrinkled corner. He carefully  straightens it out with his foot. His back is to the arch as he hears high heels clicking on the staircase. He turn and looks through the arch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room was still stuffy  from last night's cigars. The windows  were closed and the sunshine coming  in through the Venetian blinds showed  up the dust in the air. The furniture  was kind of corny and old-fashioned,  but it had a comfortable look, as if  people really sat in it. On the piano,  in couple of fancy frames, were Mr.  Dietrichson and Lola, his daughter  by his first wife They had a bowl of  those little red goldfish on the  table behind the davenport, but, to  tell you the truth, Keyes, I wasn't  a whole lot interested in goldfish  right then, nor in auto renewals,  nor in Mr. Dietrichson and his  daughter Lola. I was thinking about  that dame upstairs, and the way she  had looked at me, and I wanted to  see her again, close, without that  silly staircase between us.

dialogues.speaker: A-26 STAIRCASE, (FROM NEFF'S POINT OF VIEW)
dialogues.text: Phyllis Dietrichson is coming downstairs. First we see he feet, with pom-pom slippers and the gold anklet on her le ankle. CAMERA PULLS BACK SLOWLY as she descends, until we see all of her. She is wearing a pale blue summer dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't long, was I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, Mrs. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope I've got my face on straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's perfect for my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Crossing to the mirror  over the fireplace) Won't you sit down, Mr. -- Neff is  the name, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With two f's, like in Philadelphia.  If you know the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Philadelphia story. What are we  talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (She works with her  lipstick) About the insurance. My husband never  tells me anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on your two cars, the La Salle  and the Plymouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to the davenport to get the policies from his  briefcase. She turns away from the mirror and sits in a b chair with her legs drawn up sideways, the anklet now cle visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been handling this insurance  for three years for Mr. Dietrichson... (His eyes have caught  the anklet) That's a honey of an anklet you're  wearing, Mrs. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis smiles faintly and covers the anklet with her dre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd hate to see the policies lapse.  Of course, we give him thirty days.  That's all we're allowed to give.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess he's been too busy down at  Long Beach in the oil fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I catch him home some evening  for a few minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose so. But he's never home  much before eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be fine with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not connected with the  Automobile Club, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the All-Risk, Mrs. Dietrichson.  Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody from the Automobile Club  has been trying to get him. Do they  have a better rate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your husband's a member.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis rises and walks up and down, paying less and less attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he'd have to join the club and  pay a membership fee to start with.  The Automobile Club is fine. I never  knock the other fellow's merchandise,  Mrs. Dietrichson, but I can do just  as well for you. I have a very  attractive policy here. It wouldn't  take me two minutes to put it in  front of your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He consults the policies he is holding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For instance, we're writing a new  kind of fifty percent retention  feature in the collision coverage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis stops in her walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a smart insurance man, aren't  you, Mr. Neff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had eleven years of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing pretty well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You handle just automobile insurance,  or all kinds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down again, in the same position as before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All kinds. Fire, earthquake, theft,  public liability, group insurance,  industrial stuff and so on right  down the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accident insurance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accident insurance? Sure, Mrs.  Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes fall on the anklet again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you'd tell me what's engraved  on that anklet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just my name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As for instance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis. I think I like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have to drive it around the block  a couple of times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Standing up again) Mr. Neff, why don't you drop by  tomorrow evening about eight-thirty.  He'll be in then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband. You were anxious to talk  to him weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, only I'm getting over it a  little. If you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a speed limit in this state,  Mr. Neff. Forty-five miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How fast was I going, officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say about ninety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose you get down off your  motorcycle and give me a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose I let you off with a warning  this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose it doesn't take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose I have to whack you over the  knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose I bust out crying and put my  head on your shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose you try putting it on my  husband's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That tears it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff takes his hat and briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight-thirty tomorrow evening then,  Mrs. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I suggested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both move toward the archway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be here, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so. I usually am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same chair, same perfume, same anklet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Opening the door) I wonder if I know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if you wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting past Neff's parked car towards the entrance door which is just closing. Neff comes towards the car, swingi his briefcase. He opens the car door and looks back with confident smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Over scene) She liked me. I could feel that. The  way you feel when the cards are...

dialogues.speaker: A-29 ENTRANCE DOOR, DIETRICHSON HOME
dialogues.text: In the upper panel the peep window opens and Phyllis look out after Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: falling right for you, with a nice  little pile of blue and yellow chips  in the middle of the table. Only  what I didn't know then was that I  wasn't playing her. She was playing  me -- with a deck of marked cards --  and the stakes weren't any blue and  yellow chips. They were dynamite. I  went back to the office that afternoon  to see if I had any mail. It was the  same afternoon you had that Sam  Gorlopis on the carpet, that truck  driver from Inglewood, remember,  Keyes?

dialogues.speaker: A-30 NEFF
dialogues.text: He sits in his car, presses the starter button, looking b towards the little window in the entrance door.

dialogues.speaker: A-31 ENTRANCE DOOR
dialogues.text: The peep window is quickly closed from inside.

dialogues.speaker: A-32 STREET
dialogues.text: Neff makes a U-turn and drives back down the block.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA HIGH
dialogues.text: Activity on the eleventh floor below. Typewriters working adding machines, filing clerks, secretaries, and so forth Neff, wearing his hat and carrying his briefcase, enters  from the vestibule. He walks towards his office. He passe few salesmen, etc. There is an exchange of greetings. Jus as he reaches his office a secretary comes out. She stops

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Neff, Mr. Keyes wants to see  you. He's been yelling for you all  afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he sore, or just frothing at the  mouth a little? Here, park these for  me, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her his hat and briefcase and continues right on CAMERA WITH HIM, to a door lettered:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes' voice is heard inside, plenty loud. Neff grins as opens the door and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: A-34 KEYES
dialogues.text: A minor executive office, not too tidy: large desk across one corner, good carpet, several chairs, filing cabinet  against one wall, a dictaphone on the corner of the desk. Keyes is sitting behind the desk with his coat off but hi hat on. A cigar is clamped in his mouth, ashes falling li snow down his vest, a gold chair and elk's tooth across i On the other side of the desk sits Sam Gorlopis. He is a  big, dumb bruiser, six feet three inches tall -- a dirty  work shirt and corduroy pants, rough, untidy hair, broad  face, small piggish eyes. He holds a sweat-soaked hat on knee with a hairy hand. He is chewing gum rapidly. As Nef opens the door, Keyes is giving it to Gorlopis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wise up, Gorlopis. You're not kidding  anybody with that line of bull. You're  in a jam and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sez you. All I want is my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sez you. All you're gonna get is the  cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Neff standing inside the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Walter. This is Sam Gorlopis  from Inglewood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I know Mr. Gorlopis. Wrote a  policy on his truck. How are you,  Mr. Gorlopis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't so good. My truck burned  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks cautiously sideways at Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he just planted his big foot  on the starter and the whole thing  blazed up in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And didn't even singe his eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. Look, mister. I got twenty- six hundred bucks tied up in that  truck. I'm insured with this company  and I want my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a wife, Gorlopis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I got a wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you got for dinner tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got meat loaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you make your meat loaf,  Gorlopis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Veal and pork and bread and garlic.  Greek style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much garlic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotsa garlic, Mr. Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Gorlopis. Now listen here.  Let's say you just came up here to  tell me how to make meat loaf. That's  all, understand? Because if you came  up here to claim on that truck, I'd  have to turn you over to the law,  Gorlopis, and they'd put you in jail.  No wife. No kids --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Yelling) And no meat loaf, Gorlopis!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Look, Gorlopis. Every month  hundreds of claims come to this desk.  Some of them are phonies, and I know  which ones. How do I know, Gorlopis? (He speaks as if to a  child) Because my little man tells me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What little man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little man in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pounds the pit of his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time one of those phonies comes  along he ties knots in my stomach.  And yours was one of them, Gorlopis.  That's how I knew your claim was  crooked. So what did I do? I sent a  tow car out to your garage this  afternoon and they jacked up that  burned-out truck of yours. And what  did they find, Gorlopis? They found  what was left of a pile of shavings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shavings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ones you soaked with kerosene  and dropped a match on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gorlopis cringes under the impact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Keyes, I'm just a poor  guy. Maybe I made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one way of putting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't feelin' so good, Mr. Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign this and you'll feel fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts a blank form in front of him and points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right there. It's a waiver on your  claim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gorlopis hesitates, then signs laboriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're an honest man again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I ain't got no more truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Gorlopis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Still bewildered) Goodbye, Mr. Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands up and goes slowly to the door and turns there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-six hundred bucks. That's a  lot of dough where I live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Gorlopis? Don't  you know how to open the door? Just  put your hand on the knob, turn it  to the right, pull it toward you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Doing just as Keyes  says) Like this, Mr. Keyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the boy. Now the same thing  from the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stupefied) Thank you, Mr. Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out, closing the door after him. Keyes takes his  cigar stub from his mouth and turns it slowly in the flam of a lighted match. He turns to Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of an outfit is this anyway?  Are we an insurance company, or a  bunch of dimwitted amateurs, writing  a policy on a mugg like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Keyes. I don't rate  this beef. I clipped a note to that  Gorlopis application to have him  thoroughly investigated before we  accepted the risk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you did, Walter. I'm not  beefing at you. It's the company.  The way they do things. The way they  don't do things. The way they'll  write anything just to get it down  on the sales sheet. And I'm the guy  that has to sit here up to my neck  in phony claims so they won't throw  more money out of the window than  they take in at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Grinning) Okay, turn the record over and let's  hear the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get darn sick of picking up after  a gang of fast-talking salesmen dumb  enough to sell life insurance to a  guy that sleeps in the same bed with  four rattlesnakes. I've had twenty- six years of that, Walter, and I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you loved every minute of it,  Keyes. You love it, only you worry  about it too much, you and your little  man. You're so darn conscientious  you're driving yourself crazy. You  wouldn't even say today is Tuesday  without you looked at the calendar,  and then you would check if it was  this year's or last year's calendar,  and then you would find out what  company printed the calendar, then  find out if their calendar checks  with the World Almanac's calendar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough from you, Walter. Get  out of here before I throw my desk  at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out, still grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff comes out of Keys' office and walks back along the  balcony. Activity of secretaries going in and out of door etc. Neff enters his own office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Over scene) I really did, too, you old crab,  always yelling your fat head off,  always sore at everyone. But behind  the cigar ashes on your vest I kind  of knew you had a heart as big as a  house... Back in my office there was  a phone message from Mrs. Dietrichson  about the renewals. She didn't want  me to come tomorrow evening. She  wanted me to come Thursday afternoon  at three-thirty instead. I had a lot  of stuff lined up for that Thursday  afternoon, including a trip down to  Santa Monica to see a couple of live  prospects about some group insurance.  But I kept thinking about Phyllis  Dietrichson and the way that anklet  of hers cut into her leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson, a salesman, sits at one of the desks, filling o a report. Neff enters, goes to his own desk. He looks dow at some mail. On top there is a typewritten note. He read it, sits down and leafs through his desk calendar.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP
dialogues.text: Showing date: THURSDAY 23 May and five or six appointment penciled in tightly on the page.

dialogues.speaker: A-38 DIETRICHSON HOME
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA PANS with Phyllis Dietrichson's feet and ankle as she comes down the stairs, her high heels clicking on tiles. The anklet glistens on her leg as she moves. THE C PANS ON. Phyllis has reached the entrance hall, and as sh walks toward the front door her whole body becomes visibl She wears a gay print dress with a wide sash over her hip She opens the door. Outside is Neff, wearing a sport coat flannel slacks. He takes his hat off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands there with a little smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you coming in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm considering it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you didn't mind my changing  the appointment. Last night wasn't  so convenient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. I was working on my  stamp collection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads him toward living room.

dialogues.speaker: A-39 DIETRICHSON LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Phyllis and Neff come through archway. She heads toward a low tea table which stands in front of the davenport, wit tall glasses, ice cubes, lemon, a pot of tea, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just fixing some iced tea.  Would you like a glass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you have a bottle of beer  that's not working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There might be some. I never know  what's in the ice box. (Calls) Nettie!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pours herself a glass of tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About those renewals, Mr. Neff. I  talked to my husband about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He'll renew with you he told  me. In fact, I thought he'd be here  this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Calls again,  impatiently) Nettie!... Nettie!... Oh, I forgot,  it's the maid's day off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother, Mrs. Dietrichson. I'd  like some iced tea very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemon? Sugar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fix it your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She fixes him a glass of tea while he is looking around. slowly sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing it's the maid's day off maybe  there's something I can do for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him the tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like running the vacuum cleaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to peddle vacuum cleaners.  Not much money but you learn a lot  about life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think you'd learned it from  a correspondence course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you pick up this tea  drinking? You're not English, are  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Californian. Born right here in  Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say native Californians all  come from Iowa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to ask you something, Mr.  Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Walter, on this insurance --  how much commission do you make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty percent. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe I could throw a little  more business your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can always use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking about my husband. I  worry a lot about him, down in those  oil fields. It's very dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for an executive, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't just sit behind a desk.  He's right down there with the  drilling crews. It's got me worried  sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean a crown block might fall on  him some rainy night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't talk like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other day a casing line snapped  and caught the foreman. He's in the  hospital with a broken back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got me jittery just thinking  about it. Suppose something like  that happened to my husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think he ought to have  accident insurance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of insurance could he have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough to cover doctors' and hospital  bills. Say a hundred and twenty-five  a week cash benefit. And he'd rate  around fifty thousand capital sum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capital sum? What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's if he got killed. Maybe I  shouldn't have said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you have to think of  everything in your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dietrichson would understand.  I'm sure I could sell him on the  idea of some accident protection.  Why don't I talk to him about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could try. But he's pretty tough  going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all tough at first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a lot on his mind. He doesn't  want to listen to anything except  maybe a baseball game on the radio.  Sometimes we sit all evening without  saying a word to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds pretty dull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I just sit and knit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you married him for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I like the way his thumbs hold  up the wool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anytime his thumbs get tired --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to ask you something, Mr.  Neff. Could I get an accident policy  for him -- without bothering him at  all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would make it easier for you,  too. You wouldn't even have to talk  to him. I have a little allowance of  my own. I could pay for it and he  needn't know anything about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Why shouldn't he know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I know he doesn't want  accident insurance. He's superstitious  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of people are. Funny, isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there was a way to get it like  that, all the worry would be over.  You see what I mean, Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I've got good eyesight. You  want him to have the policy without  him knowing it. And that means without  the insurance company knowing that  he doesn't know. That's the set-up,  isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything wrong with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's lovely. And then, some  dark wet night, if that crown block  fell on him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What crown block?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only sometimes they have to have a  little help. They can't quite make  it on their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, it doesn't have to be a  crown block. It can be a car backing  over him, or he can fall out of an  upstairs window. Any little thing  like that, as long as it's a morgue  job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that crazy. Goodbye, Mrs.  Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, baby, you can't get away with  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away with what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to knock him off, don't  you, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a horrible thing to say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd you think I was, anyway? A guy  that walks into a good-looking dame's  front parlor and says "Good afternoon,  I sell accident insurance on husbands.  You got one that's been around too  long? Somebody you'd like to turn  into a little hard cash? Just give  me a smile and I'll help you collect."  Boy, what a dope I must look to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're rotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're swell. So long as I'm  not your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet I will. You bet I'll get out  of here, baby. But quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out. She looks after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff bangs the front door shut, walks quickly to his car drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Over scene) So I let her have it, straight between  the eyes. She didn't fool me for a  minute, not this time. I knew I had  hold of a redhot poker and the time  to drop it was before it burned my  hand off. I stopped at a drive-in  for a bottle of beer, the one I had  wanted all along, only I wanted it  worse now, to get rid of the sour  taste of her iced tea, and everything  that went with it. I didn't want to  go back to the office, so I dropped  by a bowling alley at Third and  Western and rolled a few lines to  get my mind thinking about something  else for a while.

dialogues.speaker: A-41 DRIVE-IN RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: Shooting past Neff sitting behind the wheel of his car Th car hop hangs a tray on the door and serves him a bottle beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff bowling. He rolls the ball with an effort at  concentration, but his mind is not really on the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is late afternoon. The apartment house is called the L OLIVOS APARTMENTS. It is a six-story building in the Norm Wilshire district, with a basement garage. THE CAMERA PAN UP the front of the building to the top floor windows, as little rain starts to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Continuing) I didn't feel like eating dinner  when I left, and I didn't feel like  a show, so I drove home, put the car  away and went up to my apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a double apartment of conventional design, with kit dinette, and bathroom, squarecut overstuffed borax furnit Gas logs are lit in the imitation fireplace. Neff stands the window with his coat off and his tie loose. Raindrops strike against the glass. He turns away impatiently, pace up and down past a caddy bag with golf clubs in it, pulls one out at random, makes a couple of short swings, throws the club on the couch, paces again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Continuing) It had begun to rain outside and I  watched it get dark and didn't even  turn on the light. That didn't help  me either. I was all twisted up  inside, and I was still holding on  to that red-hot poker. And right  then it came over me that I hadn't  walked out on anything at all, that  the hook was too strong, that this  wasn't the end between her and me.  It was only the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Continuing) So at eight o'clock the bell would  ring and I would know who it was  without even having to think, as if  it was the most natural thing in the  world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff goes to the door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff just looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forgot your hat this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has nothing in her hands but her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down at her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want me to bring it in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Put it on the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes in. He closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know where I live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in the phone book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff switches on the standing lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it is. Peel off your coat and sit  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to take off her coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long Beach. They're spudding in a  new well. He phoned he'd be late.  About nine-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her coat and lays it across the back of a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about time you said you're glad  to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you wouldn't leave it like  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like it was this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must have said something that gave  you a terribly wrong impression. You  must surely see that. You must never  think anything like that about me,  Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not okay. Not if you don't  believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to be nice to me. Like  the first time you came to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be like the first time.  Something has happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it has. It's happened to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis has moved over to the window. She stares out thro the wet window-pane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel as if he was watching me. Not  that he cares about me. Not any more.  But he keeps me on a leash. So tight  I can't breathe. I'm scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What of? He's in Long Beach, isn't  he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I oughtn't to have come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you oughtn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time, he has hold of her wrist. He draws her to h slowly and kisses her. Her arms tighten around him. After moment he pulls his head back, still holding her close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How were you going to do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, for the last time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to jerk away but he holds her and kisses her ag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm crazy about you, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm crazy about you, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That perfume on your hair. What's  the name of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something French. I bought it down  at Ensenada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ought to have some of that pink  wine to go with it. The kind that  bubbles. But all I have is bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourbon is fine, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets her go and moves toward the dinette.

dialogues.speaker: A-45 THE DINETTE AND KITCHEN
dialogues.text: It contains a small table and some chairs. A low glass-an china cabinet is built between the dinette and kitchen,  leaving a space like a doorway. The kitchen is the usual  apartment house kitchen, with stove, ice-box, sink, etc. is quite small. Neff goes to the ice-box and Phyllis drifts in after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plain water, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a couple of glasses, will you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points at the china closet. He has taken a tray of ice cubes from the refrigerator and is holding it under the h water faucet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, about six months ago a guy  slipped on the soap in his bathtub  and knocked himself cold and drowned.  Only he had accident insurance. So  they had an autopsy and she didn't  get away with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis has the glasses now. She hands them to him. He du some ice cubes into the glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who didn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for the whiskey bottle on top of the china clo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there was another case where a  guy was found shot and his wife said  he was cleaning a gun and his stomach  got in the way. All she collected  was a three-to-ten stretch in  Tehachapi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps it was worth it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff hands her a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See if you can carry this as far as  the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move back toward the living room.

dialogues.speaker: A-46 LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Phyllis and Neff go toward the davenport. She is sipping drink and looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice here, Walter. Who takes  care of it for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A colored woman comes in twice a  week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get your own breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once in a while I squeeze a  grapefruit. The rest I get at the  corner drugstore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit on the davenport, fairly close together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds wonderful. Just strangers  beside you. You don't know them. You  don't hate them. You don't have to  sit across the table and smile at  him and that daughter of his every  morning of your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What daughter? Oh, that little girl  on the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Lola. She lives with us. He  thinks a lot more of her than he  does of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever think of a divorce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't give me a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose because it would cost him  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't got any money. Not since  he went into the oil business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he had when you married him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he had. And I wanted a home.  Why not? But that wasn't the only  reason. I was his wife's nurse. She  was sick for a long time. When she  died, he was all broken up. I pitied  him so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now you hate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Walter. He's so mean to me.  Every-time I buy a dress or a pair  of shoes he yells his head off. He  won't let me go anywhere. He keeps  me shut up. He's always been mean to  me. Even his life insurance all goes  to that daughter of his. That Lola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing for you at all, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. And nothing is just what I'm  worth to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you lie awake in the dark and  listen to him snore and get ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, I don't want to kill him. I  never did. Not even when he gets  drunk and slaps my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only sometimes you wish he was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you wish it was an accident, and  you had that policy. For fifty  thousand dollars. Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps that too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a long drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other night we drove home from a  party. He was drunk again. When we  got into the garage he just sat there  with his head on the steering wheel  and the motor still running. And I  thought what it would be like if I  didn't switch it off, just closed  the garage door and left him there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what it would be like,  if you had that accident policy, and  tried to pull a monoxide job. We  have a guy in our office named Keyes.  For him a set-up like that would be  just like a slice of rare roast beef.  In three minutes he'd know it wasn't  an accident. In ten minutes you'd be  sitting under the hot lights. In  half an hour you'd be signing your  name to a confession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Walter, I didn't do it. I'm not  going to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if there's an insurance company  in the picture, baby. So long as  you're honest they'll pay you with a  smile, but you just try to pull  something like that and you'll find  out. They know more tricks than a  carload of monkeys. And if there's a  death mixed up in it, you haven't  got a prayer. They'll hang you as  sure as ten dimes will buy a dollar,  baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to cry. He puts his arms around her and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stop thinking about it, will  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds her tight. Their heads touch, side by side, THE  CAMERA SLOWLY STARTS TO RECEDE as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff sits in the swivel chair, talking into the dictaphon He has hooked the wastebasket under his feet to sit more  comfortably. As he talks, a little cough shakes him now a then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we just sat there, and she kept  on crying softly, like the rain on  the window, and we didn't say  anything. Maybe she had stopped  thinking about it, but I hadn't. I  couldn't. Because it all tied up  with something I had been thinking  about for years, since long before I  ever ran into Phyllis Dietrichson.  Because, in this business you can't  sleep for trying to figure out the  tricks they could pull on you. You're  like the guy behind the roulette  wheel, watching the customers to  make sure they don't crook the house.  And then one night, you get to  thinking how you could crook the  house yourself. And do it smart.  Because you've got that wheel right  under your hands. And you know every  notch in it by heart. And you figure  all you need is a plant out in front,  a shill to put down the bet. And  suddenly the doorbell rings and the  whole set-up is right there in the  room with you... Look, Keyes, I'm  not trying to whitewash myself. I  fought it, only maybe I didn't fight  it hard enough. The stakes were fifty  thousand dollars, but they were the  life of a man, too, a man who'd never  done me any dirt. Except he was  married to a woman he didn't care  anything about, and I did...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY towards the davenport again. Neff sit in one corner with his feet on the low table. He is smoki his cigarette and staring at the ceiling. Phyllis has bee sitting fairly close to him. She gets up slowly and cross to her rain coat, lying over a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go now, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff does not answer. He keeps on staring at the ceiling. She starts to put the rain coat on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you call me, Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff still does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her slowly, almost absently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate him. I loathe going back to  him. You believe me, don't you,  Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stand it anymore. What if  they did hang me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to hang, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's better than going on this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you're not going to hang, baby.  Not ever. Because you're going to do  it the smart way. Because I'm going  to help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what you're saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I know what I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and grips her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to do it together. We're  going to do it right. And I'm the  guy that knows how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is fierce determination in his voice. His fingers d into her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, you're hurting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't going to be any slip up.  Nothing sloppy. Nothing weak. It's  got to be perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads her towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me tomorrow. But not from your  house. From a booth. And watch your  step. Every single minute. It's got  to be perfect, understand. Straight  down the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have now reached the door. Neff opens it. Phyllis st in the doorway, her lips white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight down the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes quietly. He watches her down the corridor. Slowl he closes the door and goes back into the room. He moves  across the window and opens it wide. He stands there, loo down into the dark street. From below comes the sound of car starting and driving off. The rain drifts in against face. He just stands there motionless. His mind is going hundred miles a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff sits slumped in his chair before the dictaphone. On desk next to him stands a used record. The cylinder on th dictaphone is not turning. He is smoking a cigarette. He  kills it then lifts the needle and slides off the record  which is on the machine and stands it on end on the desk  beside the other used record. He reaches down painfully t take another record from the rack beneath the dictaphone, looks at it against the light to make sure it has not bee used, then slides it into place on the machine and resets the needle. He lifts the horn and resumes his dictation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first thing we had to do was fix  him up with that accident policy. I  knew he wouldn't buy, but all I wanted  was his signature on an application.  So I had to make him sign without  his knowing what he was signing. And  I wanted a witness other than Phyllis  to hear me give him a sales talk. I  was trying to think with your brains,  Keyes. I wanted all the answers ready  for all the questions you were going  to spring as soon as Dietrichson was  dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff takes a last drag on his cigarette and kills it by  running it under the ledge of the dictaphone stand. He dr the stub on the floor and resumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of nights later I went to  the house. Everything looked fine,  except I didn't like the witness  Phyllis had brought in. It was  Dietrichson's daughter Lola, and it  made me feel a little queer in the  belly to have her right there in the  room, playing Chinese checkers, as  if nothing was going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: GRADUALLY REVEALS THE DIETRICHSON LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: The checker-board is on the davenport between Phyllis and Lola. Mr. Dietrichson sits in a big easy chair. His coat tie are over the back of the chair, and the evening paper lying tumbled on the floor beside him. He is smoking a ci with the band on it. He has a drink in front of him and  several more inside him. In another chair sits Neff, his  briefcase on the floor, leaning against his chair. He hol his rate book partly open, with a finger in it for a mark He is going full swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you realize, Mr.  Dietrichson, that, not being an  employee, you are not covered by the  State Compensation Insurance Act.  The only way you can protect yourself  is by having a personal policy of  your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know all about that. The next thing  you'll tell me I need earthquake  insurance and lightning insurance  and hail insurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis looks up from the checker-board and cuts in on th dialogue. Lola listens without much interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Dietrichson) If we bought all the insurance they  can think up, we'd stay broke paying  for it, wouldn't we, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What keeps us broke is you going out  and buying five hats at a crack. Who  needs a hat in California?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always say insurance is a lot like  a hot water bottle. It looks kind of  useless and silly hanging on the  hook, but when you get that stomach  ache in the middle of the night, it  comes in mighty handy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you want to sell me a hot water  bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollar for dollar, accident insurance  is the cheapest coverage you can  buy, Mr. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe some other time, Mr. Neff. I  had a tough day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as you say, Mr. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose we just settle that automobile  insurance tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. All we need on that is for you  to sign an application for renewal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis throws a quick glance at Neff. As she looks back sees that Lola is staring down at her wrist watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis, do you mind if we don't  finish this game? It bores me stiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got some thing better to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Dietrichson) Father, is it all right if I run  along now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run along where? Who with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just Anne. We're going roller skating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Matthews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that Nino Zachetti again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It better not be that Zachetti guy.  If I ever catch you with that ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Anne Matthews, I told you. I  also told you we're going roller  skating. I'm meeting her at the corner  of Vermont and Franklin -- the north- west corner, in case you're  interested. And I'm late already. I  hope that is all clear. Good night,  Father. Good night, Phyllis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Miss Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry. Good night, Mr. --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're not going to take my car  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. I'd rather be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes out through the archway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great little fighter for her weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dietrichson sucks down a big swallow of his drink. Neff has taken two blank forms from his briefcase. He put the briefcase on Mr. Dietrichson's lap and lays the forms top. Phyllis is watching closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where you sign, Mr.  Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The applications for your auto  renewals. So you'll be protected  until the new policies are issued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When will that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In about a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so I'm covered when I drive up  North.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff takes out his fountain pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: San Francisco, Mr. Dietrichson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palo Alto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a Stanford man, Mr. Neff. And  he still goes to his class reunion  every year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with that? Can't I have  a little fun even once a year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great football school, Stanford. Did  you play football, Mr. Dietrichson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left guard. Almost made the varsity,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff has unscrewed his fountain pen. He hands it to Mr.  Dietrichson. Dietrichson puts on his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On that bottom line, Mr. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dietrichson signs. Neff's and Phyllis' eyes meet for a sp second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both copies, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He withdraws the top copy barely enough to expose the  signature line on the supposed duplicate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign twice, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One is the agent's copy. I need it  for my files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a mutter) Files. Duplicates. Triplicates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dietrichson grunts and signs again. Again Neff and Phylli exchange a quick glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No hurry about the check, Mr.  Dietrichson. I can pick it up at  your office some morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casually Neff lifts the briefcase and signed applications off Dietrichson's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you taking me for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One forty-seven fifty, Mr.  Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dietrichson stands up. He is about Neff's height but a li heavier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that's enough insurance for  one evening, Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dietrichson has poured some more whisky into his glass. H tries the siphon but it is empty. He gathers up his coat tie and picks up his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff is zipping up his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mr. Dietrichson. Good  night, Mrs. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring me some soda when you come up,  Phyllis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dietrichson trundles off towards the archway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Neff) I think you left your hat in the  hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis leads the way and Neff goes after her, his briefc under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: B-3 HALLWAY DIETRICHSON RESIDENCE
dialogues.text: Phyllis enters through the living room archway with Neff  behind her. She leads him towards the door. On the way he picks up his hat. In the BACKGROUND Dietrichson begins to ascend the stairs, carrying his coat and glass. Phyllis a Neff move close to the door. They speak in very low voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He signed it, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure he signed it. You saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis opens the door a crack. Both look at the stairs,  where Dietrichson is going up. Phyllis takes her hand off the doorknob and holds on to Neff's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking up) Watch it, will you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis slowly drops her hand from his arm. Both look up Dietrichson goes across the balcony and out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. That trip to Palo Alto When  does he go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: End of the month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He always drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this time. You're going to make  him take the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's all worked out for a  train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a second they stand listening and looking up as if th had heard a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. Go on, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, baby. There's a clause in every  accident policy, a little something  called double indemnity. The insurance  companies put it in as a sort of  come-on for the customers. It means  they pay double on certain accidents.  The kind that almost never happen.  Like for instance if a guy got killed  on a train, they'd pay a hundred  thousand instead of fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. (Her eyes widen with  excitement)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're hitting it for the limit, baby.  That's why it's got to be a train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be a train, Walter.  Just the way you say. Straight down  the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other. The look is like a long kiss. Ne goes out. Slowly Phyllis closes the door and leans her he against it as she looks up the empty stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff, briefcase under his arm, comes down the steps to th street, where his Dodge coupe is parked at the curb. He o the door and stops, looking in. Sitting there in the dark corner of the car, away from th steering wheel, is Lola. She wears a coat but no hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Neff. It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lola gives him a sly smile. Neff is a little annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me? What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you could let me ride with  you, if you're going my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff doesn't like the idea very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way would that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the hill. Down Vermont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Remembering) Oh, sure. Vermont and Franklin. North- west corner, wasn't it? Be glad to,  Miss Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff puts the briefcase on the ledge behind the driver's  seat. He closes the door and starts the car. They drift d the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roller skating, eh? You like roller  skating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take it or leave it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff looks at her curiously. Lola meets his glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only tonight you're leaving it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an embarrassing moment for Lola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. You see, Mr. Neff, I'm  having a very tough time at home. My  father doesn't understand me and  Phyllis hates me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That does sound tough, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I have to lie sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean it's not Vermont and  Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Vermont and Franklin all right.  Only it's not Anne Matthews. It's  Nino Zachetti. You won't tell on me,  will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have to think it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
