dialogues.text: Nino's not what my father says at  all. He just had bad luck. He was  doing pre-med at U.S.C. and working  nights as an usher in a theater  downtown. He got behind in his credits  and flunked out. Then he lost his  job for talking back. He's so hot- headed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That comes expensive, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess my father thinks nobody's  good enough for his daughter except  maybe the guy that owns Standard  Oil. Would you like a stick of gum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never use it, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lola puts a stick of gum in her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't give Nino up. I wish father  could see it my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll straighten out all right, Miss  Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose it will sometime. (Looking out) This is the corner right here, Mr.  Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff brings the car to a stop by the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is. By the bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff looks out.

dialogues.speaker: B-6 CORNER VERMONT AND FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Zachetti stands waiting, hands in trouser pockets. He is  about twenty-five, Italian looking, open shirt, not well  dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs a hair-cut, doesn't he.  Look at him. No job, no car, no money,  no prospects, no nothing. (Pause) I love him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans over and honks on the horn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Calling) Nino!

dialogues.speaker: B-8 ZACHETTI
dialogues.text: He turns around and looks towards the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over here, Nino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachetti walks towards the car.

dialogues.speaker: B-9 THE COUPE
dialogues.text: Neff and Lola. She has opened the door. Zachetti comes up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Neff, Nino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Nino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Belligerent from the  first word) The name is Zachetti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nino. Please. Mr. Neff gave me a  ride from the house. I told him all  about us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does he have to get told about  us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have to worry about Mr.  Neff, Nino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not doing any worrying. Just  don't you broadcast so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you, Nino?  He's a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have any friends. And if I  did, I like to pick them myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, sonny, she needed the ride and  I brought her along. Is that anything  to get tough about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Lola, make up your mind.  Are you coming or aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm coming. Don't mind  him, Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lola steps out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot. You've been very sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lola catches up with Zachetti and they walk away together

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff looks after them. Slowly he puts the car in gear and drives on. His face is tight. Behind his head, light catc the metal of the zipper on the briefcase. Over the shot c the COMMENTARY:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a nice kid and maybe he was  a little better than he sounded. I  kind of hoped so for her sake, but  right then it gave me a nasty feeling  to be thinking about them at all,  with that briefcase right behind my  head and her father's application in  it. Besides, I had other problems to  work out. There were plans to make,  and Phyllis had to be in on them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a fair amount of activity but the place is not  crowded. Neff comes along the sidewalk into the shot. He  passes in front of the fruit and vegetable display and go between the stalls into the market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Continued) ...but we couldn't be seen together  any more and I had told her never to  call me from her house and never to  call me at my office. So we had picked  out a big market on Los Feliz. She  was to be there buying stuff every  day about eleven o'clock, and I could  run into her there. Kind of  accidentally on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff stops by the cashier's desk and buys a pack of  cigarettes. As he is opening the pack he looks back casua beyond the turnstile into the rear part of the market.

dialogues.speaker: B-13 ROWS OF HIGH SHELVES IN MARKET
dialogues.text: The shelves are loaded with canned goods and other  merchandise. Customers move around selecting articles and putting them in their baskets. Phyllis is seen among them standing by the soap section. Her basket is partly filled She wears a simple house dress, no hat, and has a large  envelope pocketbook under her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff has spotted Phyllis. Without haste he passes through the turnstile towards the back.

dialogues.speaker: B-15 THE SHELVES
dialogues.text: Phyllis is putting a can of cleaning powder into her bask Neff enters the shot and moves along the shelves towards  her, very slowly, pretending to inspect the goods. A cust passes and goes on out of scene. Phyllis and Neff are now very close. During the ensuing low-spoken dialogue, they  continue to face the shelves, not looking at each other

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk to you, Walter.  Ever since yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me talk first. It's all set. The  accident policy came through. I've  got it in my pocket. I got his check  too. I saw him down in the oil fields.  He thought he was paying for the  auto insurance. The check's just  made out to the company. It could be  for anything. But you have to send a  check for the auto insurance, see.  It's all right that way, because one  of the cars is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But listen, Walter ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick, open your bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates, then opens it. Neff looks around quickly,  slips the policy out of his pocket and drops it into her  bag. She snaps the bag shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you get into his safe deposit  box?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. We both have keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. But don't put the policy in  there yet. I'll tell you when. And  listen, you never touched it or even  saw it, understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. When is he taking the train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, that's just it. He isn't  going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I've been trying to tell  you. The trip is off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off as a short, squatty woman, pushing a child a walker, comes into sight and approaches. She stops besi Neff, who is pretending to read a label on a can. Phyllis puts a few cakes of soap into her basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Neff) Mister, could you reach me that can  of coffee? (She points) That one up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reaching up) This one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods. Neff reaches a can down from the high shelf and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see why they always have to  put what I want on the top shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves away with her coffee and her child. Out of the  corner of his eye Neff watches her go. He moves closer to Phyllis again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had a fall down at the well. He  broke his leg. It's in a cast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That knocks it on the head all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do, Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until he can take a train. I told  you it's got to be a train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't wait. I can't go on like  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to grab a hammer and  do it quick, just to get it over  with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are other ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only we're not going to do it other  ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we can't leave it like this.  What do you think would happen if he  found out about this accident policy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty. But not as bad as sitting in  that death-house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ever talk like that, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't let's start losing our  heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not our heads. It's our nerve  we're losing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to do it right. That's  all I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter maybe it's my nerves. It's  the waiting that gets me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting me just as bad, baby.  But we've got to wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we have, Walter. Only it's so  tough without you. It's like a wall  between us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye baby. I'm thinking of you  every minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes off. She stares after him.

dialogues.speaker: B-16 NEFF'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: He is wearing a light grey suit and has his hat on. He is standing behind his desk opening some mail, taking a few  papers out of his briefcase, checking something in his ra book, making a quick telephone call. But nothing of this heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After that a full week went by and I  didn't see her once. I tried to keep  my mind off her and off the whole  idea. I kept telling myself that  maybe those fates they say watch  over you had gotten together and  broken his leg to give me a way out.  Then it was the fifteenth of June.  You may remember that date, Keyes. I  do too, only for a very different  reason. You came into my office around  three in the afternoon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes enters with some papers in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just came from Norton's office.  The semi-annual sales records are  out. You're high man, Walter. That's  twice in a row. Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. How would you like a cheap  drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like a fifty dollar  cut in salary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would I -- Do I laugh now, or  wait until it gets funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious, Walter. I've been talking  to Norton. There's too much stuff  piling up on my desk. Too much  pressure on my nerves. I spend half  the night walking up and down in my  bed. I've got to have an assistant.  I thought that you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Why pick on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I've got a crazy idea you  might be good at the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's crazy all right. I'm a  salesman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. A peddler, a glad-hander, a  back-slapper. You're too good to be  a salesman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's too good to be a salesman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phooey. All you guys do is ring door- bells and dish out a smooth line of  monkey talk. What's bothering you is  that fifty buck cut, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'd bother anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Walter. The job I'm talking  about takes brains and integrity. It  takes more guts than there is in  fifty salesman. It's the hottest job  in the business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still a desk job. I don't want  a desk job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A desk job. Is that all you can see  in it? Just a hard chair to park  your pants on from nine to five.  Just a pile of papers to shuffle  around, and five sharp pencils and a  scratch pad to make figures on, with  maybe a little doodling on the side.  That's not the way I see it, Walter.  To me a claims man is a surgeon, and  that desk is an operating table, and  those pencils are scalpels and bone  chisels. And those papers are not  just forms and statistics and claims  for compensation. They're alive,  they're packed with drama, with  twisted hopes and crooked dreams. A  claims man, Walter, is a doctor and  a blood-hound and a cop and a judge  and a jury and a father confessor,  all in one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephone rings on Neff's desk. Automatically Keyes g the phone and answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Okay, hold the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the phone down on the desk and continues to Neff:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you want to tell me you're not  interested. You don't want to work  with your brains. All you want to  work with is your finger on a door- bell. For a few bucks more a week.  There's a dame on your phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff picks the phone up and answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Neff speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to call you, Walter. It's  terribly urgent. Are you with  somebody?

dialogues.speaker: B-18 NEFF'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Neff on the phone. His eye catches Keyes', who is walking and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I am. Can't I call you  back... Margie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, I've only got a minute. It  can't wait. Listen. He's going  tonight. On the train. Are you  listening, Walter? Walter!

dialogues.speaker: B-20 NEFF
dialogues.text: His eyes are on Keyes. He speaks into the phone as calmly possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm listening. Only make it short...  Margie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on crutches. The doctor says he  can go if he's careful. The change  will do him good. It's wonderful,  Walter. Just the way you wanted it.  Only with the crutches it's ever so  much better, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: B-22 NEFF'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Neff on phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred percent better. Hold the  line a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He covers the receiver with his hand and turns to Keyes, is now standing at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose I join you in your office,  Keyes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a gesture as if expecting Keyes to leave. Keyes  stays right where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait. Only tell Margie not to  take all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff looks at Keyes' back with a strained expression, the lifts the phone again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the ten-fifteen from Glendale.  I'm driving him. Is it still that  same dark street?

dialogues.speaker: B-24 NEFF, ON PHONE
dialogues.text: He is still watching Keyes cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The signal is three honks on the  horn. Is there anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What color did you pick out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Color? (She catches on) Oh, sure. The blue suit, Walter.  Navy blue. And the cast on his left  leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navy blue. I like that fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it, Walter. I'm shaking like  a leaf. But it's straight down the  line now for both of us. I love you,  Walter. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: B-28 NEFF'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Neff on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, Margie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. His mouth is grim, but he forces a smile as  Keyes turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? The dames chasing  you again? Or still? Or is it none  of my business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With a sour smile) If I told you it was a customer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie! I bet she drinks from the  bottle. Why don't you settle down  and get married, Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you, for instance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I almost did, once. A long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff gets up from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Keyes, I've got a prospect to  call on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes drives right ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We even had the church all picked  out, the dame and I. She had a white  satin dress with flounces on it. And  I was on my way to the jewelry store  to buy the ring. Then suddenly that  little man in here started working  on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He punches his stomach with his fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you went back and started  investigating her. That it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes nods slowly, a little sad and a little ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the stuff that came out. She'd  been dyeing her hair ever since she  was sixteen. And there was a manic- depressive in her family, on her  mother's side. And she already had  one husband, a professional pool  player in Baltimore. And as for her  brother --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get the general idea. She was a  tramp from a long line of tramps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up some papers impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'm going. What am I to  say to Norton? How about that job I  want you for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I want it. Thanks,  Keyes, just the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough. Just get this: I picked  you for the job, not because I think  you're so darn smart, but because I  thought maybe you were a shade less  dumb than the rest of the outfit. I  guess I was all wet. You're not  smarter, Walter. You're just a little  taller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out. Neff is alone. He watches the door close, th turns and goes slowly to the water cooler. He fills a pap cup and stands holding it. His thoughts are somewhere els After a moment he absently throws the cupful of water int the receptacle under the cooler. He goes back to the desk He takes his rate book out of his brief case and puts it the desk. He buttons the top button of his shirt, and pul his tie right. He leaves the office, with his briefcase u his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was it, Keyes, and there was no  use kidding myself any more. Those  fates I was talking about had only  been stalling me off. Now they had  thrown the switch. The gears had  meshed. The machinery had started to  move and nothing could stop it. The  time for thinking had all run out.  From here on it was a question of  following the time table, move by  move, just as we had it rehearsed. I  wanted my time all accounted for for  the rest of the afternoon and up to  the last possible moment in the  evening. So I arranged to call on a  prospect in Pasadena about a public  liability bond. When I left the office  I put my rate book on the desk as if  I had forgotten it. That was part of  the alibi.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEFF'S APT. HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: Neff's coupe comes down the street and swings into the ga and goes down the ramp into the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got home about seven and drove  right into the garage. This was  another item to establish my alibi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are about eight cars parked. A colored attendant in coveralls and rubber boots is washing a car with a hose a sponge. Neff's car comes into the shot and stops near the attendant. Neff gets out with his briefcase under his arm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya there, Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a wash job on my heap,  Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How soon you want it, Mr. Neff? I  got two cars ahead of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anytime you get to it, Charlie. I'm  staying in tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Neff. Be all shined up for  you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff is crossing to the elevator. He speaks back over his shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That left front tire looks a little  soft. Check it, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet. Check 'em all round. Always  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff enters the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: B-31 NEFF'S APT.
dialogues.text: Neff enters. He walks straight to the phone, dials, and s speaking into the mouthpiece, but only the COMMENTARY is  heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up in my apartment I called Lou  Schwartz, one of the salesmen that  shared my office. He lived in  Westwood. That made it a toll call  and there'd be a record of it. I  told him I had forgotten my rate  book and needed some dope on the  public liability bond I was figuring.  I asked him to call me back. This  was another item in my alibi, so  that later on I could prove that I  had been home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff comes into the living room from the bedroom, putting the jacket of his blue suit. THE PHONE RINGS. He picks up the receiver and starts talking, unheard, as before. He m notes on a pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I changed into a navy blue suit like  Dietrichson was going to wear. Lou  Schwartz called me back and gave me  a lot of figures...

dialogues.speaker: B-33 NEFF
dialogues.text: He is folding a hand towel and stuffing it into his jacke pocket. He then takes a large roll of adhesive tape and p that into his pants pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cont'd) I stuffed a hand towel and a big  roll of adhesive tape into my pockets,  so I could fake something that looked  like a cast on a broken leg... Next  I fixed the telephone and the  doorbell, so that the cards would  fall down if the bells rang. That  way I would know there had been a  phone call or visitor while I was  away. I left the apartment house by  the fire stairs and side door. Nobody  saw me. It was already getting dark.  I took the Vermont Avenue bus to Los  Feliz and walked from there up to  the Dietrichson house. There was  that smell of honeysuckle again,  only stronger, now that it was  evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-34 & B-35 INSERTS OF OPEN TELEPHONE BELL BOX (ON BA & DOORBELL (ABOVE ENTRANCE DOOR) Neff's hand places a small card against the bell clapper each of these.

dialogues.speaker: B-36 FIRE STAIRS, APT. HOUSE, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS with Neff going down the stairs in his blue s with a hat pulled down over his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TRAFFIC
dialogues.text: Some windows are lit. Neff comes into the shot and approa cautiously. He looks around and then slides open the gara door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff closes the garage door. Very faint light comes in at side window. He opens the rear door of the sedan, gets in and closes the door after him. The dark interior of the c has swallowed him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I was in the garage. His car  was backed in, just the way I told  Phyllis to have it. It was so still  I could hear the ticking of the clock  on the dashboard. I kept thinking of  the place we had picked out to do  it, that dark street on the way to  the station, and the three honks on  the horn that were to be the signal...  About ten minutes later they came  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door has opened and Dietrichson is half-way dow the steps. He is walking with crutches, wearing the dark  blue suit and a hat. The cast is on his left leg. There i no shoe on his left foot. Only the white plaster shows.  Phyllis comes after him, carrying his suitcase and his  overcoat. She wears a camel's-hair coat and no hat. She  catches up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, honey? I'll have the  car out in a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dietrichson just grunts. She passes him to the garage, CA WITH HER, and slides the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA IS VERY LOW INSIDE THE SEDAN, shooting slightl upwards from Neff's hiding place. The garage door has jus been opened. Phyllis comes to the car, opens the rear doo She looks down, almost INTO THE CAMERA. A tight, cool smi flashes across her face. Then, very calmly, she puts the  suitcase and overcoat in back on the seat (out of shot). closes the door again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dietrichson stands watching Phyllis as she gets into the and drives out to pick him up. She stops beside him and o the right-hand door. Dietrichson climbs in with difficult She helps him, watching him closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, honey. We've got lots  of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let me do it my own way. Grab  that crutch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes one of the crutches from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ought to make these things so  they fold up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment, as he leans his hand on the back of the sea there is danger that he may see Neff. He doesn't. He slid awkwardly into the seat and pulls the second crutch in af him. He closes the door. The car moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis driving and Dietrichson beside her, face TOWARDS CAMERA. Dietrichson has a partly smoked cigar between his teeth. They are in the middle of a conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, stop squawkin' can't you, Phyllis?  No man takes his wife along to a  class reunion. That's what class  reunions are for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Tucker went along with her  husband last year, didn't she.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and what happened to her? She  sat in the hotel lobby for four days  straight. Never even saw the guy  until we poured him back on the train.

dialogues.speaker: DIETRICHSON
dialogues.text: His face is partly covered by the edge of a traveling rug which he has pulled up over him. He looks up at Dietrichs and Phyllis in the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, honey. Just so long as  you have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't do much dancing, I can tell  you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-44 HEADS & SHOULDERS OF DIETRICHSON & PHYLLIS -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember what the doctor said. If  you get careless you might end up  with a shorter leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? I could break the other one  and match them up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes you feel pretty good to get  away from me, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-45 PHYLLIS & DIETRICHSON - FACING CAMERA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only for four days. I'll be  back Monday at the latest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget we're having the Hobeys  for dinner on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hobeys? We had them last. They  owe us a dinner, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they do but I've already asked  them for Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want to feed the Hobeys.

dialogues.speaker: PHYLLIS' FACE ONLY
dialogues.text: There is a look of tension in her eyes now. She glances a quickly. The car has reached the dark street Neff and she picked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't want to eat at their  house either. The food you get there,  and that rope he hands out for cigars.  Call it off, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis does not answer. She doesn't even breathe. Her ha goes down on the horn button. She honks three times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing that for? What  the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is as far as his voice will ever get. It breaks off dies down in a muffled groan. There are struggling noises and a dull sound of something breaking. Phyllis drives on and never turns her head. She stares straight in front of her. Her teeth are clenched.

dialogues.speaker: B-47 PARKING SPACE ADJOINING GLENDALE STATION
dialogues.text: The station is visible about sixty yards away. There is n parking attendant. Ten or twelve cars are parked diagonal not crowded. The train is not in yet, but there is activi around the station. Passengers and their friends, redcaps and baggage men, news vendors, etc. The Dietrichson sedan drives into the shot past CAMERA an parks in the foreground at the outer end of the line, sev spaces from the next car, facing away from the CAMERA. Bo front doors are open. Phyllis gets out and from the other side crutches emerge, and a man (seen entirely from behin and apparently Dietrichson) climbs out awkwardly. While h is steadying himself on the ground with the crutches, Phy has taken out Dietrichson's suitcase and overcoat. She wa around the car and rolls up the right front window. She c and locks the car door. She tries the right rear door and takes a last look into the dim interior of the car. Then and the man walk slowly away from the car to the end of t station platform and along it toward the station building Phyllis walks several steps ahead of the man. B-48 PHYLLIS & THE MAN - WALKING CAMERA FOLLOWING THEM, a little to one side, so that Phyl is clearly seen but the man's face is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a subdued voice) You handle the redcap and the  conductor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep them away from me as much as  you can. I don't want to be helped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said don't worry, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-49 PHYLLIS & THE MAN, WALKING DOWN PLATFORM, CAMERA

dialogues.speaker: PRECEDING THEM
dialogues.text: Only at this point is it quite clear that THE MAN IS NEFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You start just as soon as the train  leaves. At the dairy sign you turn  off the highway onto the dirt road.  From there it's exactly eight-tenths  of a mile to the dump beside the  tracks. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be there a little ahead of  the train. No speeding. You don't  want any cops stopping you -- with  him in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, we've been through all that  so many times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you turn off the highway, cut  all your lights. I'm going to be  back on the observation platform.  I'll drop off as close to the spot  as I can. Wait for the train to pass,  then blink your lights twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis nods. They go on. Over them is heard the noise of the train coming into the station and its lights are seen

dialogues.speaker: B-50 GLENDALE STATION PLATFORM
dialogues.text: The train is just coming to a stop. The passengers move  forward to the tracks. Phyllis, carrying the suitcase and overcoat, and Neff, still a little behind her, come TOWAR THE CAMERA. A redcap sees them and runs up. He takes the  suitcase out of Phyllis' hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: San Francisco train, lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis takes an envelope containing Dietrichson's ticket from the pocket of the overcoat. She reads from the envel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car nine, section eleven. Just my  husband going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car nine, section eleven. Yessum,  this way please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis hands the overcoat to the redcap, who leads her a Neff towards car number nine. Neff still hangs back and k his head down, the way a man using crutches might natural do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pullman conductor and porter stand at the steps. The  conductor is checking the tickets of passengers getting o The redcap leads Phyllis and Neff into the SHOT. The cond and porter see Neff on his crutches and move to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, thanks. My husband  doesn't like to be helped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The redcap goes up the steps into the car. Neff laborious swings himself up onto the box and from there up on the s keeping his head down. Meantime, Phyllis is holding the  attention of the conductor and porter by showing them the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car nine, section eleven. The  gentleman only. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis nods and takes the ticket back. Neff has reached top of the steps. She goes up after him and gives him the ticket. They are now close together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, honey. Take awful good care  of yourself with that leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I will. Just you take it easy  going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll miss you, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him. There are shouts of "ALL ABOARD". The red comes from inside the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Section eleven, suh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis takes a quarter from her bag and gives it to the  redcap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shouting) All aboard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redcap descends. Phyllis kisses Neff again quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs down the steps. The porter picks up the box. He the conductor get on board the train. Phyllis stands ther waving goodbye as the train starts moving, and the porter begins to close the car door. Phyllis turns and walks out the shot in the direction of the parked car.

dialogues.speaker: DIM LIGHT
dialogues.text: Neff and the Porter. The conductor is going on into the c Neff is half turned away from the porter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you make up my berth right away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going back to the observation  car for a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, sir. Three cars back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds the vestibule door open. Neff hobbles through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the berths are made up. As Neff hobbles along, an porter and some passengers make way for the crippled man  solicitously.

dialogues.speaker: B-56 PLATFORM BETWEEN TWO CARS
dialogues.text: The train conductor meets Neff and opens the door for him Neff hobbles on through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four or five passengers are reading or writing. As Neff c through on his crutches they pull in their feet to make r for him. One old lady, seeing that he is headed for the  observation platform, opens the door for him. He thanks h with a nod and hobbles through.

dialogues.speaker: B-58 OBSERVATION PLATFORM
dialogues.text: Dark except for a little light coming from inside the par car. The train is going at about fifteen miles an hour be Glendale and Burbank. Neff has come out and hobbled to th railing. He stands looking back along the rails. SUDDENLY MAN'S VOICE speaks from behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I pull a chair out for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff looks around. He sees a man sitting in the corner sm a hand-rolled cigarette. He is about fifty-five years old with white hair, and a broad-brimmed Stetson hat. He look like a small town lawyer or maybe a mining man. Neff does not like the man's presence there very much. He turns to just enough to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, I'd rather stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palo Alto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Jackson. I'm going all the  way to Medford. Medford, Oregon. Had  a broken arm myself once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That darn cast sure itches something  fierce, don't it? I thought I'd go  crazy with mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff stands silent. His mind is feverishly thinking of ho to get rid of Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palo Alto's a nice little town. You  a Stanford man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts patting his pockets as if looking for something

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you left something behind. I  always do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cigar case. Must have left it in  my overcoat back in the section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson takes out a small bag of tobacco and a packet of  cigarette papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Care to roll yourself a cigarette,  Mr. --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dietrichson. Thanks. I really prefer  cigars. (Looking around) Maybe the porter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could get your cigars for you. Be  glad to, Mr. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's darn nice of you. It's car  nine, section eleven. If you're sure  it's not too much trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car nine, section eleven. A pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises and exits into the parlor car. Neff turns slowly and watches Jackson go back through the car. Then he move to one side of the platform and looks ahead along the tra to orientate himself. He gives one last glance back into parlor car to make sure no one is watching him. He slips crutches from under his arms and stands on both feet. He  drops the crutches off the train onto the tracks, then qu swings his body over the rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff is hanging onto the railing. He looks down, then let go and drops to the right-of-way. THE CAMERA STOPS. The t recedes slowly into the night. Neff has fallen on the tra He picks himself up, rubs one knee and looks back along t line of the tracks and off to one side.

dialogues.speaker: B-60 DARK LANDSCAPE
dialogues.text: Close beyond the edge of the right-of-way, the silhouette a dump shows up. Beside it looms the dark bulk of the  Dietrichson sedan. The headlights blink twice and go out.

dialogues.speaker: B-61 NEFF
dialogues.text: He starts running towards the car. He runs a little awkwa because of the improvised cast on his left foot.

dialogues.speaker: B-62 CAR IN THE DARK
dialogues.text: The front door opens and Phyllis steps out. She closes th door and looks in the direction of the tracks. The uneven steps of Neff running towards her are heard. She opens th back door of the car and leans in. She pulls the rug off corpse (which is not visible) and stands looking into the car, unable to take her eyes off what she sees, while at same time her hands mechanically begin to fold the rug. T running steps grow louder and Neff comes into the SHOT  breathing hard. He reaches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. This has to go fast. Take his  hat and pick up the crutches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff points back towards the tracks. He reaches into the and begins to drag out the body by the armpits. Phyllis c reaches past him and takes the hat off the dead man's hea She turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on to that rug. I'll need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis moves out of the shot carrying the hat and rug.

dialogues.speaker: B-63 NEFF
dialogues.text: He gets a stronger hold on the dead Dietrichson and drags him free of the car and towards the tracks. The corpse is not seen.

dialogues.speaker: B-64 PHYLLIS
dialogues.text: She has reached the point where one of the crutches lies. She picks it up and goes for the other crutch a short dis away. She carries both crutches, the hat and the rug towa Neff.

dialogues.speaker: B-65 NEFF
dialogues.text: He has reached the railroad tracks. The corpse is lying b the tracks, face down. Phyllis comes up to Neff. He takes the crutches and the hat from her. He throws the crutches beside the corpse. He takes the hat from Phyllis and toss it carelessly along the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. Stay behind me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the rug from her and they move back towards the  car, Phyllis first, then Neff walking almost backwards,  sweeping the ground over which the body was dragged with rug as they go.

dialogues.speaker: B-66 THE CAR
dialogues.text: They reach it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in. You drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets in. Neff sweeps the ground after him as he goes  around the car to get in beside her. He throws the rug in the back of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis is behind the wheel. Neff beside her is just clos the door. He props his wrapped foot against the dashboard and begins to tear off the adhesive tape while at the sam time Phyllis presses the starter button. The starter grin but the motor doesn't catch. She tries again. It still do catch. Neff looks at her. She tries a third time. The sta barely turns over. The battery is very low. Phyllis leans back. They stare at each other desperately. After a moment Neff bends forward slowly and turns the  ignition key to the OFF position. He holds his left thumb poised over the starter button. There is a breathless mom Then he presses the starter button with swift decision. T starter grinds with nerve-wracking sluggishness. Neff twi the ignition key to ON and instantly pulls the hand-throt wide open. With a last feeble kick of the starter, the mo catches and races. He eases the throttle down and slides  back into his place. They look at each other again. The  tenseness of the moment still shows in their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis releases the hand brake and puts the car in rever Neff is again busy unwrapping the tape from his leg. The moves.

dialogues.speaker: B-68 DARK LANDSCAPE
dialogues.text: The car, with the headlights out, backs up, swings around and moves off along the dirt road the way it came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis and Neff facing towards CAMERA. Neff is bent over peeling the towel and plaster off his foot, which is out shot. Phyllis is calm, almost relaxed. Neff straightens u They are talking to each other. Their lips are seen movin but what they say is not heard. They stop talking. Phylli stares straight ahead. Neff is pulling adhesive tape off wrapped towel that was on his foot. He folds the adhesive into a tight ball, rolls the towel up, puts both into his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the way back we went over once  more what she was to do at the  inquest, if they had one, and about  the insurance, when that came up. I  was afraid she might go to pieces a  little, now that we had done it, but  she was perfect. No nerves. Not a  tear, not even a blink of the eyes...

dialogues.speaker: B-70 DARK STREET NEAR NEFF'S APT. HOUSE
dialogues.text: The sedan drives into the shot and stops without pulling  over to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cont'd) She dropped me a block from my  apartment house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car door opens. Neff starts to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff turns back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Walter. Aren't  you going to kiss me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I'm going to kiss you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis bends towards him and puts her arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's straight down the line, isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis kisses him. In the kiss he is passive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, baby.

dialogues.speaker: B-71 FIRE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Neff going up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was two minutes past eleven as I  went up the fire stairs again. Nobody  saw me this time either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telephone bell box and the door bell. The cards are still position. Neff's hand takes them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cont'd) In the apartment I checked the bells.  The cards hadn't moved. No calls. No  visitors.

dialogues.speaker: B-74 LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Neff comes from the bedroom, wearing the light grey suit wore before the murder, only with out a tie. He buttons h jacket, looks around the room, and opens the corridor doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I changed the blue suit. There was  one last thing to do. I wanted the  garage man to see me again.

dialogues.speaker: B-75 BASEMENT GARAGE
dialogues.text: Fifteen or twenty cars are parked now. Charlie, the atten has washed Neff's car and is now polishing the glass and  metal work. Neff comes from the elevator. Charlie sees hi He straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to need it after all, Mr.  Neff? I'm about through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Charlie. Just walking  down to the drug store for something  to eat. Been working upstairs all  evening. My stomach's getting sore  at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks up the ramp towards the garage entrance.

dialogues.speaker: GARAGE ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: Neff comes out at the top of the ramp and starts to walk  down the street, not too fast. CAMERA PRECEDES HIM. He wa about ten or fifteen yards. At first his steps sound hard and distinct on the sidewalk and echo in the deserted str But slowly, as he goes on, they fade into utter silence. walks a few feet without sound, then becomes aware of the silence. He stops rigidly and looks back. CAMERA STOPS WI HIM. He stands like that for a moment, then turns toward CAMERA again. There is a look of horror on his face now. walks on, CAMERA AHEAD OF HIM again. Still his steps make sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was all there was to it. Nothing  had slipped, nothing had been  overlooked, there was nothing to  give us away. And yet, Keyes, as I  was walking down the street to the  drug store, suddenly it came over me  that everything would go wrong. It  sounds crazy, Keyes, but it's true,  so help me: I couldn't hear my own  footsteps. It was the walk of a dead  man.

dialogues.speaker: C-1 NEFF'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Neff sits before the dictaphone. There are four cylinders end on the desk next to him. He gets up from the swivel c with great effort and stands a moment unsteadily. The wou in his shoulder is paining him. He is very weak as he slo crosses to the water cooler. He takes the blood stained  handkerchief from inside his shirt and soaks it with fres water. The office door opens behind him. He turns, hiding the  handkerchief behind his back. In the doorway stands the  colored man who has been cleaning up downstairs. He is  carrying his big trash box by a rope handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't know anybody was here, Mr.  Neff. We ain't cleaned your office  yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it go tonight. I'm busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you say, Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the door slowly, staring at Neff with an uneasy expression. Neff puts the soaked handkerchief back on his wounded shoulder, then walks heavily over to his swivel c and lowers himself into it. He takes the dictaphone horn speaks into it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the longest night I ever  lived through, Keyes, and the next  day was worse, when the story broke  in the papers, and they were talking  about it at the office, and the day  after that when you started digging  into it. I kept my hands in my pockets  because I thought they were shaking,  and I put on dark glasses so people  couldn't see my eyes, and then I  took them off again so people wouldn't  get to wondering why I wore them. I  was trying to hold myself together,  but I could feel my nerves pulling  me to pieces....

dialogues.speaker: C-2 INSURANCE OFFICE
dialogues.text: Neff comes through the reception room doors with his hat and his briefcase under his arm. He walks towards his off but half way there he runs into Keyes. Keyes is wearing h vest and hat, no coat. He is carrying a file of papers an smoking a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Walter. The big boss wants  to see us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks beside Keyes, CAMERA AHEAD of them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Dietrichson case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy's dead, we had him insured  and it's going to cost us money.  That's always wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops by a majolica jar full of sand and takes a penci from his vest. He stands over the jar extinguishing his c carefully so as not to damage it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got so far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autopsy report. No heart failure, no  apoplexy, no predisposing medical  cause of any kind. He died of a broken  neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When is the inquest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had it this morning. His wife  and daughter made the identification.  The train people and some passengers  told how he went through to the  observation car.. It was all over in  forty-five minutes. Verdict,  accidental death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes puts the half-smoked cigar into his vest pocket wit the pencil. They move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do the police figure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That he got tangled up in his crutches  and fell off the train. They're  satisfied. It's not their dough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop at a door lettered in embossed chromium letters EDWARD S. NORTON, JR. PRESIDENT. Keyes opens the door. Th go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A secretary sitting behind a desk. As Keyes and Neff ente the door to Norton's private office is opened. From insid Mr. Norton is letting out three legal looking gentlemen.  Norton is about forty-five, very well groomed, rather pom in manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To the men who are  leaving) I believe the legal position is now  clear, gentlemen. Please stand by. I  may need you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Keyes and Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Mr. Keyes. You too, Mr.  Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff has put down his hat and briefcase. He and Keyes pas the legal looking men and follow Norton into his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally it is the best office in the building; modern b not modernistic, spacious, very well furnished; flowers,  smoking stands, easy chairs, etc. Norton has gone behind desk. Keyes has come in, and Neff after him closes the do quietly. Norton looks disapprovingly at Keyes' shirt slee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You find this an uncomfortably warm  day Mr. Keyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes takes his hat off but holds it in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Norton. I didn't know  this was formal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norton smiles frostily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, gentlemen. (To Keyes) Any new developments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes and Neff sit down, Norton remains standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just talked to this Jackson long  distance. Up in Medford, Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Jackson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last guy that saw Dietrichson  alive. They were out on the  observation platform together talking.  Dietrichson wanted a cigar and Jackson  went to get Dietrichson's cigar case  for him. When he came back to the  observation platform, no Dietrichson.  Jackson didn't think anything was  wrong until a wire caught up with  the train at Santa Barbara. They had  found Dietrichson's body on the tracks  near Burbank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very interesting, about the cigar  case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks up and down behind his desk thinking hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much. Dietrichson's secretary  says she didn't know anything about  the policy. There is a daughter, but  all she remembers is Neff talking to  her father about accident insurance  at their house one night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't sell him at first. Mrs.  Dietrichson opposed it. He told me  he'd think it over. Later on I went  down to the oil fields and closed  him. He signed the application and  gave me his check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Dripping with sarcasm) A fine piece of salesmanship that  was, Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no sense in pushing Neff  around. He's got the best sales record  in the office. Are your salesmen  supposed to know that the customer  is going to fall off a train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fall off a train? Are we sure  Dietrichson fell off the train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a charged pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't, Mr. Keyes? Then what do  you think of this case? This policy  might cost us a great deal of money.  As you know, it contains a double  indemnity clause. Just what is your  opinion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No opinion at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even a hunch? One of those  interesting little hunches of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. Not even a hunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised, Mr. Keyes. I've formed  a very definite opinion. I think I  know -- in fact I know I know what  happened to Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you know what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it was not an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks from Keyes to Neff and back to Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say to that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? You've got the ball. Let's see  you run with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a widespread feeling that  just because a man has a large office --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dictograph on his desk buzzes. He reaches over and  depresses a key and puts the earpiece to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into dictograph) Yes?... Have her come in, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He replaces the earpiece. He turns back to Keyes and Neff

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- that just because a man has a  large office he must be an idiot.  I'm having a visitor, if you don't  mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes and Neff start to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. I want you to stay and watch  me handle this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The secretary has opened the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff stands staring at the door. He relaxes with an obvio effort of will. Phyllis comes in. She wears a gray tailor suit, small black hat with a veil, black gloves, and carr a black bag. The secretary closes the door behind her. Mr Norton goes to meet her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much for coming, Mrs.  Dietrichson. I assure you I appreciate  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns a little towards Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've met Mr. Neff. How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norton has placed a chair. Phyllis sits. Norton goes behi his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dietrichson, I assure you of  our sympathy in your bereavement. I  hesitated before asking you to come  here so soon after your loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis nods silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now that you're here I hope you  won't mind if I plunge straight into  business. You know why we asked you  to come, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. All I know is that your secretary  made it sound very urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes sits quietly in his chair with his legs crossed. He has hung his hat on his foot and thrust his thumbs in the armholes of his vest. He looks a little bored. Neff, behi him, stands leaning against the false mantel, completely  dead-pan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband had an accident policy  with this company. Evidently you  don't know that, Mrs. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I remember some talk at the house --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks towards Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but he didn't seem to want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He took it out a few days later,  Mrs. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll probably find the policy among  his personal effects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His safe deposit box hasn't been  opened yet. It seems a tax examiner  has to be present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mrs. Dietrichson, I don't  want you to think you are being  subjected to any questioning. But  there are a few things we should  like to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have the report of the coroner's  inquest. Accidental death. We are  not entirely satisfied. In fact we  are not satisfied at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis looks at him coolly. Keyes looks vaguely interested. Neff is staring straight at Phyllis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, Mrs. Dietrichson, we suspect  suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis doesn't bat an eyelash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Would you like a glass of  water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates a thermos on a stand near Neff. Neff pours a glass of water and carries it over to Phyllis. She has li her veil a little. She takes the glass from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes meet for a fraction of a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had your husband been moody or  depressed lately, Mrs. Dietrichson?  Did he seem to have financial worries,  for instance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was perfectly all right and I  don't know of any financial worries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must have been something, Mrs.  Dietrichson. Let us examine this so- called accident. First, your husband  takes out this policy in absolute  secrecy. Why? Because he doesn't  want his family to suspect what he  intends to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commit suicide. Next, he goes on  this trip entirely alone. He has to  be alone. He hobbles all the way out  to the observation platform, very  unlikely with his leg in a cast,  unless he has a very strong reason.  Once there, he finds he is not alone.  There is a man there. What was his  name, Keyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norton flips his fingers impatiently at Keyes who doesn't even bother to look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name was Jackson. Probably still  is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson. So your husband gets rid of  this Jackson with some flimsy excuse  about cigars. And then he is alone.  And then he does it. He jumps.  Suicide. In which case the company  is not liable. (Pause) You know that, of course. We could  go to court --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know anything. In fact I  don't know why I came here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes as if to rise indignantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a moment, please. I said we  could go to court. I didn't say we  want to. Not only is it against our  practice, but it would involve a  great deal of expense, a lot of  lawyers, a lot of time, perhaps years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis rises coldly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what I want to suggest is a  compromise on both sides. A settlement  for a certain sum, a part of the  policy value --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother, Mr. Norton. When I  came in here I had no idea you owed  me any money. You told me you did.  Then you told me you didn't. Now you  tell me you want to pay me a part of  it, whatever it is. You want to  bargain with me, at a time like this.  I don't like your insinuations about  my husband, Mr. Norton, and I don't  like your methods. In fact I don't  like you, Mr. Norton. Goodbye,  gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and walks out. The door closes after her. There a pregnant pause. Keyes straightens up in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice going, Mr. Norton. You sure  carried that ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norton pours himself a glass of water and stands holding

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only you fumbled on the goal line.  Then you heaved an illegal forward  pass and got thrown for a forty-yard  loss. Now you can't pick yourself up  because you haven't got a leg to  stand on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't eh? Let her claim. Let her  sue. We can prove it was suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we? Mr. Norton, the first thing  that hit me was that suicide angle.  Only I dropped it in the wastepaper  basket just three seconds later. You  ought to take a look at the statistics  on suicide sometime. You might learn  a little something about the insurance  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was raised in the insurance  business, Mr. Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. In the front office. Come on,  you never read an actuarial table in  your life. I've got ten volumes on  suicide alone. Suicide by race, by  color, by occupation, by sex, by  seasons of the year, by time of day.  Suicide, how committed: by poisons,  by fire-arms, by drowning, by leaps.  Suicide by poison, subdivided by  types of poison, such as corrosive,  irritant, systemic, gaseous, narcotic,  alkaloid, protein, and so forth.  Suicide by leaps, subdivided by leaps  from high places, under wheels of  trains, under wheels of trucks, under  the feet of horses, from steamboats.  But Mr. Norton, of all the cases on  record there's not one single case  of suicide by leap from the rear end  of a moving train. And do you know  how fast that train was going at the  point where the body was found?  Fifteen miles an hour. Now how could  anybody jump off a slow moving train  like that with any kind of expectation  that he would kill himself? No soap,  Mr. Norton. We're sunk, and we're  going to pay through the nose, and  you know it. May I have this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes' throat is dry after the long speech. He grabs the  glass of water out of Norton's hand and drains it in one gulp. Norton is watching him almost stupefied. Neff stands with the shadow of a smile on his face. Keyes puts the glass d noisily on Norton's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norton doesn't move or speak. Keyes puts his hat on and  crosses towards the door, Neff after him. With the doorkn in his hand Keyes turns back to Norton with a glance down his own shirt sleeves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time I'll rent a tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go out.

dialogues.speaker: C-5 NEFF
dialogues.text: There is a tired grin on his face as he talks into the ho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could have hugged you right then  and there, Keyes, you and your  statistics. You were the only one we  were really scared of, and instead  you were almost playing on our team...

dialogues.speaker: C-6 NEFF'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: The corridor door opens letting light in. Neff enters wit his hat on and his briefcase under his arm. He switches t lights on, closes the door, puts the lights on, closes th door, puts the key in his pocket. At this moment the tele rings. He picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That evening when I got home my nerves  had eased off. I could feel the ground  under my feet again, and it looked  like easy going from there on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... Hello, baby.... Sure,  everything is fine... You were  wonderful in Norton's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis is on the phone. She is not dressed as in Norton' office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt so funny. I wanted to look at  you all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you think I felt? Where are  you, baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the drug store. Just a block away.  Can I come up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. But be careful. Don't let  anybody see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, takes off his hat and drops hat and briefcas on the davenport. He looks around the room and crosses to lower the venetian blinds and draw the curtains. He gathe up the morning paper which is lying untidily on the floor and puts it in the waste-paper basket. The door bell rings. Neff stops in sudden alarm. It can't be Phyllis. The time too short. For a second he stands there motionless, then  crosses to the door and opens it. In the open door stands Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes walks past him into the room. His hands are clasped behind his back. There is a strange, absent-minded look i his eyes. Neff closes the door without taking his eyes of Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes stops in the middle of the room and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That broken leg. The guy broke his  leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talking about Dietrichson. He had  accident insurance, didn't he? Then  he broke his leg, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he didn't put in a claim. Why  didn't he put in a claim? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the dickens are you driving at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter. There's something wrong. I  ate dinner two hours ago. It stuck  half way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He prods his stomach with his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little man is acting up again.  Because there's something wrong with  that Dietrichson case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he didn't put in a claim?  Maybe he just didn't have time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh maybe he just didn't know he was  insured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has stopped in front of Neff. They look at each other a tense moment. Neff hardly breathes. Keyes shakes his head suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That couldn't be it. You delivered  the policy to him personally, didn't  you, Walter? And you got his check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stiff-lipped, but  his voice is as well  under control as he  can manage) Sure, I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes prods his stomach again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any bicarbonate of soda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes resumes his pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Walter. I've been living  with this little man for twenty-six  years. He's never failed me yet.  There's got to be something wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Norton was right. Maybe it was  suicide, Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not suicide. (Pause) But not accident either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is another longer pause, agonizing for Neff. Finall Keyes continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. A man takes out an accident  policy that is worth a hundred  thousand dollars if he is killed on  a train. Then, two weeks later, he  is killed on a train. And not in a  train accident, mind you, but falling  off some silly observation car. Do  you know what the mathematical  probability of that is, Walter? One  out of I don't know how many billions.  And add to that the broken leg. It  just can't be the way it looks,  Walter. Something has been worked on  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes doesn't answer. He goes on pacing up and down. Fina Neff can't stand the silence any longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Prods stomach again) Don't you have any peppermint or  anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (Pause) Who do you suspect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I like to make things easy for  myself. But I always tend to suspect  the beneficiary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. That wide-eyed dame that didn't  know anything about anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy, Keyes. She wasn't even  on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know she wasn't, Walter. I don't  claim to know how it was worked, or  who worked it, but I know that it  was worked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to the corridor door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to get to a drug store. It  feels like a hunk of concrete inside  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his hand on the knob to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: C-11 CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: The hallway is empty except for Phyllis who has been stan close to the door of Neff's apartment, listening. The doo has just started to open. Phyllis moves away quickly and  flattens herself against the wall behind the opening door Keyes is coming out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff, behind him, looks anxiously down the hallway for  Phyllis. Suddenly his eye catches a glimpse of her throug the crack of the partly opened door. He pushes the door w so as to hide her from Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you at the office in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has reached the elevator. He pushes the call button an turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'd like to move in on her right  now, tonight, if it wasn't for Norton  and his stripe-pants ideas about  company policy. I'd have the cops  after her so quick her head would  spin. They'd put her through the  wringer, and, brother, what they  would squeeze out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only you haven't got a single thing  to go on, Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator has come up and stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too much. Twenty-six years  experience, all the percentage there  is, and this lump of concrete in my  stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls back the elevator door and turns to Neff with on last glance of annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Almost angrily) No bicarbonate of soda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes gets into the elevator. The door closes. The elevat goes down. Neff stands numb, looking at the spot where Keyes was las visible. Without moving his eyes he pulls the door around towards him with his left hand. Phyllis slowly comes out. Neff motions quickly to her to go into the apartment. She crosses in front of him and enters. He steps in backwards after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis has come a few steps into the room. Neff, backing after her, closes the door from inside and turns slowly.  They look at each other for a long moment in complete sil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much does he know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not what he knows. It's those  stinking hunches of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he can't prove anything, can he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if we're careful. Not if we don't  see each other for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For how long a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves toward him but he does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until all this dies down. You don't  know Keyes the way I do. Once he  gets his teeth into something he  won't let go. He'll investigate you.  He'll have you shadowed. He'll watch  you every minute from now on. Are  you afraid, baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm afraid. But not of Keyes.  I'm afraid of us. We're not the same  any more. We did it so we could be  together, but instead of that it's  pulling us apart. Isn't it, Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't really care whether we  see each other or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her close and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: D-1 INSURANCE OFFICE
dialogues.text: Two telephone operators and a receptionist are at work.  Several visitors are waiting in chairs. Lola Dietrichson one of them. She's wearing a simple black suit and hat,  indicating mourning. Her fingers nervously pick at a  handkerchief and her eyes are watching the elevator doors anxiously. (Now and then the telephone operators in the background a heard saying, "PACIFIC ALL-RISK. GOOD AFTERNOON.") The elevator comes up and the doors open. Several people  come out, among them Neff, carrying his briefcase. Lola s him and stands up, and as he is about to pass through the anteroom without recognizing her she stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff looks at her a little startled.
