dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice hangs in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lola Dietrichson. Don't you remember  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On his guard) Yes. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I talk to you, just for a few  minutes? Somewhere where we can be  alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Come on into my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes the swing door open and holds it for her. As sh passes in front of him his eyes narrow in uneasy speculat

dialogues.speaker: D-2 TWELFTH FLOOR
dialogues.text: Neff comes up level with Lola and leads her towards his  office, CAMERA WITH THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it something to do with -- what  happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Neff. It's about my father's  death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry, Miss Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door of his office and holds it for her. She enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lou Schwartz, one of the other salesmen, is working at hi desk. Lola enters, Neff after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Schwartz) Lou, do you mind if I use the office  alone for a few minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all yours, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and goes out. Lola has walked over to the wind and is looking out so Schwartz won't stare at her. Neff p a chair beside his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sound of the closing door she turns and speaks wit catch in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Neff, I can't help it, but I  have such a strange feeling that  there is something queer about my  father's death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queer? Queer in what way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I should be bothering  you with my troubles, except that  you knew my father and knew about  the insurance he took out. And you  were so nice to me that evening in  your car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. We got along fine, didn't we.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down. His face is grim and watchful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me, Mr. Neff. I'm not crazy.  I'm not hysterical. I'm not even  crying. But I have the awful feeling  that something is wrong, and I had  the same feeling once before -- when  my mother died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When your mother died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were up at Lake Arrowhead. That  was six years ago. We had a cabin  there. It was winter and very cold  and my mother was very sick with  pneumonia. She had a nurse with her.  There were just the three of us in  the cabin. One night I got up and  went into my mother's room. She was  delirious with fever. All the bed  covers were on the floor and the  windows were wide open. The nurse  wasn't in the room. I ran and covered  my mother up as quickly as I could.  Just then I heard a door open behind  me. The nurse stood there. She didn't  say a word, but there was a look in  her eyes I'll never forget. Two days  later my mother was dead. (Pause) Do you know who that nurse was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff stares at her tensely. He knows only too well who th nurse was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis. I tried to tell my father,  but I was just a kid then and he  wouldn't listen to me. Six months  later she married him and I kind of  talked myself out of the idea that  she could have done anything like  that. But now it's all back again,  now that something has happened to  my father, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not making sense, Miss  Dietrichson. Your father fell off a  train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and two days before he fell off  that train what was Phyllis doing?  She was in her room in front of a  mirror, with a black hat on, and she  was pinning a black veil to it, as  if she couldn't wait to see how she  would look in mourning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. You've had a pretty bad shock.  Aren't you just imagining all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I caught her eyes in the mirror, and  they had that look in them they had  before my mother died. That same  look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like your step-mother, do  you? Isn't it just because she is  your step-mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loathe her. Because she did it.  She did it for the money. Only you're  not going to pay her, are you, Mr.  Neff? She's not going to get away  with it this time. I'm going to speak  up. I'm going to tell everything I  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better be careful, saying things  like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid. You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns again to the window so he won't see that she is crying. Neff gets up and goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to act like  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this that you've been telling me --  who else have you told?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about your step-mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. I'm not living in the  house any more. I moved out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you didn't tell that boy-friend  of yours? Zachetti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not seeing him any more. We had  a fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you living then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got myself a little apartment in  Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four walls, and you just sit and  look at them, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns from the window with a pathetic little nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Through her tears) Yes, Mr. Neff.

dialogues.speaker: D-4 LA GOLONDRINA, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: In the foreground, Neff and Lola are having dinner. In th background the usual activity of Olvera Street -- sidewal peddlers, guitar players, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I took her to dinner that evening  at a Mexican joint down on Olvera  Street where nobody would see us. I  wanted to cheer her up..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff and Lola driving along the beach near Santa Monica.  Neff is wearing a light summer suit, very much in contras to Lola's mourning. Apparently she is telling him a story and now and then she laughs, but there is no sound. CAMERA MOVES PAST HER TO A: CLOSE SHOT OF NEFF behind the steering wheel. He is only half listening to Lola. His mi is full of other thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next day was Sunday and we went for  a ride down to the beach. She had  loosened up a bit and she was even  laughing... I had to make sure she  wouldn't tell that stuff about Phyllis  to anybody else. It was dynamite,  whether it was true or not. And I  had no chance to talk to Phyllis.  You were watching her like a hawk,  Keyes. I couldn't even phone her for  fear you had the wires tapped.

dialogues.speaker: D-6 INSURANCE OFFICE
dialogues.text: Neff, with his hat on and no briefcase, is walking toward Keyes' office. As he comes up close to the door, he stops with a startled expression on his face. On a chair beside the door sits a familiar figure. He is Jackson, the man f the observation platform of the train. He is wearing his  Stetson hat and smoking a cigar. He is studying something the file folder. Neff recognizes him immediately but Jack does not look up. Neff controls his expression and goes o to open the door to Keyes' office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday morning there was a note on  my desk that you wanted to see me,  Keyes. For a minute I wondered if it  could be about Lola. It was worse.  Outside your door was the last guy  in the world I wanted to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff is just closing the door from the inside. Keyes, his coat off, is lying on his office couch, chewing on a ciga as usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. Come in, Walter. I want to  ask you something. After all the  years we've known each other, do you  mind if I make a rather blunt  statement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About me. Walter, I'm a very great  man. This Dietrichson business. It's  murder, and murders don't come any  neater. As fancy a piece of homicide  as anybody ever ran into. Smart and  tricky and almost perfect, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes bounces off the couch like a rubber ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: but, I think Papa has it all figured  out, figured out and wrapped up in  tissue paper with pink ribbons on  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes levels a finger at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? That guy Dietrichson  was never on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he wasn't, Walter. Look, you  can't be sure of killing a man by  throwing him off a train that's going  fifteen miles an hour. The only way  you can be sure is to kill him first  and then throw his body on the tracks.  That would mean either killing him  on the train, or -- and this is where  it really gets fancy -- you kill him  somewhere else and put him on the  tracks. Two possibilities, and I  personally buy the second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're way ahead of me, Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it was like this. They killed  the guy -- the wife and somebody  else -- and then the somebody else  took the crutches and went on the  train as Dietrichson, and then the  somebody else jumped off, and then  they put the body on the tracks where  the train had passed. An  impersonation, see. And a cinch to  work. Because it was night, very few  people were about, they had the  crutches to stare at, and they never  really looked at the man at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fancy all right, Keyes. Maybe  it's a little too fancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it? I tell you it fits together  like a watch. And now let's see what  we have in the way of proof. The  only guy that really got a good look  at this supposed Dietrichson is  sitting right outside my office. I  took the trouble to bring him down  here from Oregon. Let's see what he  has to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes goes to the door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Mr. Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson enters with the file folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, Mr. Keyes. These are fine  cigars you smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates the cigar he himself is smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two for a quarter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind the cigar, Jackson. Did  you study those photographs? What do  you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, indeed, I studied them  thoroughly. Very thoroughly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? Did you make up your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Keyes, I'm a Medford man. Medford,  Oregon. Up in Medford we take our  time making up our minds --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you're not in Medford now. I'm  in a hurry. Let's have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson indicates the file folder he is holding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are these photographs of the late  Mr. Dietrichson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then my answer is no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean this is not the man that was  on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you swear to that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a Medford man. Medford, Oregon.  And if I say it, I mean it, and if I  mean it, of course I'll swear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes turns to Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are, Walter. There's your  proof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes remembers he forgot to introduce Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Jackson, this is Mr. Neff,  one of our salesmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please to meet you, Mr. Neff. Pleased  indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very fine, thank you. Never was  better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Jackson, how would you describe  the man you saw on that observation  platform?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm pretty sure he was a younger  man, about ten or fifteen years  younger than the man in these  photographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dietrichson was about fifty, wasn't  he, Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-one, according to the policy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man I saw was nothing like fifty- one years old. Of course, it was  pretty dark on that platform and,  come to think of it, he tried to  keep his back towards me. But I'm  positive just the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine, Jackson. Now you  understand this matter is strictly  confidential. We may need you again  down here in Los Angeles, if the  case comes to court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any time you need me, I'm at your  entire disposal, gentlemen. Expenses  paid, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes picks up the telephone on his desk and speaks into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me Lubin, in the cashier's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Jackson crosses over to Neff and, during the  ensuing dialogue between him and Neff, we hear Keyes' low voice on the phone in background. We do not hear what he  says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Neff) Ever been in Medford, Mr. Neff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Do you go trout  fishing? Maybe I saw you up Klamath  Falls way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. Never fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff. Neff. I've got it! It's the  name. There's a family of Neffs in  Corvallis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No relation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see. This man's an automobile  dealer in Corvallis. Very reputable  man, too, I'm told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes rejoins them at this point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Mr. Jackson. Suppose you  go down to the cashier's office --  room twenty-seven on the eleventh  floor. They'll take care of your  expense account and your ticket for  the train tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight? Tomorrow morning would suit  me better. There's a very good  osteopath down here I want to see  before I leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes has opened the door for Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Jackson. Just don't put  her on the expense account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson doesn't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, gentlemen. A pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is, Walter. It's beginning  to come apart at the seams already.  A murder's never perfect. It always  comes apart sooner or later. And  when two people are involved it's  usually sooner. We know the  Dietrichson dame is in it, and  somebody else. Pretty soon we're  going to know who that somebody else  is. He'll show. He's got to show.  Sometime, somewhere, they've got to  meet. Their emotions are all kicked  up. Whether it's love or hate doesn't  matter. They can't keep away from  each other. They think it's twice as  safe because there are two of them.  But it's not twice as safe. It's ten  times twice as dangerous. They've  committed a murder and that's not  like taking a trolley ride together  where each one can get off at a  different stop. They're stuck with  each other. They've got to ride all  the way to the end of the line. And  it's a one-way trip, and the last  stop is the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts a cigar in his mouth and starts tapping his pocke for matches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Continued) She put in her claim and I'm going  to throw it right back at her. (Pats his pockets  again) Have you got one of those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff strikes a match for him. Keyes takes the match out o his hand and lights his cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her sue us if she dares. I'll be  ready for her -- and that somebody  else. They'll be digging their own  graves.

dialogues.speaker: D-8 TELEPHONE BOOTH IN JERRY'S MARKET
dialogues.text: Neff is in the booth dialing a number, and as she waits h looks around to make sure he is not watched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone) Mrs. Dietrichson?... This is Jerry's  market. We just got in a shipment of  that English soap you were asking  about. Will you be coming by this  morning?... Thank you, Mrs.  Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LaSalle stops in front of the market. Phyllis steps o and goes into the market, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: D-10 SHELVES IN THE REAR OF MARKET
dialogues.text: Neff is moving slowly along the shelves, outwardly calm b with his nerves on edge. From beyond him Phyllis approach She stops beside him, facing the same way, with a couple feet separating them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a harsh whisper) Come closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis moves close to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's the matter. Keyes is  rejecting your claim. He's sitting  back with his mouth watering, waiting  for you to sue. He wants you to sue.  But you're not going to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he got to stop me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got the goods. He's figured out  how it was worked. He knows it was  somebody else on the train. He's dug  up a witness he thinks will prove  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prove it how? Listen, if he rejects  that claim, I have to sue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? And then you're in court and a  lot of other things are going to  come up. Like, for instance, about  you and the first Mrs. Dietrichson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis looks at him sharply, sideways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about me and the first Mrs.  Dietrichson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way she died. And about that  black hat you were trying on -- before  you needed a black hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A customer comes along the aisle toward them. They move a The customer passes. Phyllis draws close again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, Lola's been telling you some  of her cockeyed stories. She's been  seeing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been seeing her, if you want to  know. So she won't yell her head off  about what she knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she's been putting on an act  for you, crying all over your  shoulder, that lying little --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep her out of it. All I'm telling  you is we're not going to sue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you don't want the money any  more, even if you could get it?  Because she's made you feel like a  heel all of sudden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't the money any more. It's  our necks now. We're pulling out,  understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of what Keyes can do? You're  not fooling me, Walter. It's because  of Lola. What you did to her father.  You can't take it that she might  find out some day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, leave her out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, it's me I'm talking about. I  don't want to be left out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop saying that. It's just that it  hasn't worked out the way we wanted.  We can't have the money. We can't go  through with it, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have gone through with it, Walter.  The tough part is all behind us. We  just have to hold on now and not go  soft inside, and stick together,  close, the way we started out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis takes his arm, forgetting where she is. He pulls  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it, will you. Someone's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the market help, pushing a small hand-truck loaded with packaged goods, comes along the aisle. He stops and  begins to restock a shelf very close to Neff and Phyllis. They go off slowly in opposite directions. CAMERA PANS wi Neff as he walks toward another shelf, one that stands aw from the wall. Phyllis appears on the opposite side of th shelf and stops, facing toward him. They now continue the low-voiced dialogue through the piled-up merchandise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved you, Walter. And I hated  him. But I wasn't going to do anything  about it, not until I met you. It  was you had the plan. I only wanted  him dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I was the one that fixed  him so he was dead. Is that what  you're telling me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis takes off her dark glasses for the first time and looks at him with cold, hard eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And nobody's pulling out. We  went into it together, and we're  coming out at the end together. It's  straight down the line for both of  us, remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis puts the glasses on again and goes. Over Neff's face, as he looks after her, comes the COMMEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I remembered all right. Just  as I remembered what you had told  me, Keyes, about that trolley car  ride and how there was no way to get  off -- until the end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff is dictating into the dictaphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I remembered it all right.  Just as I remembered what you had  told me, Keyes, about that trolley  car ride, and how there was no way  to get off until the end of the line,  where the cemetery was. And I got to  thinking what cemeteries are for.  They're to put dead people in, I  guess that was the first time I ever  thought about Phyllis that way. Dead,  I mean, and how things would be if  she was dead. Because the way it was  now she had me by the throat. She  could hang me higher than a kite any  day she felt like it. And there was  nothing I could do, except hold my  breath and watch that day come closer  and closer, and maybe pray a little,  if I still knew how to pray... I saw  Lola three or four times that week.  I guess it sounds crazy, Keyes, after  what I had done, but it was only  with her that I could relax and let  go a little. Then one night we drove  up into the hills above Hollywood  Bowl...

dialogues.speaker: D-12 HOLLYWOOD HILLS, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Neff and Lola are climbing over a low hill in the foregro The sky is starlit and music from the Bowl comes over the scene from below (Cesar Franck D Minor Symphony). As he h her climb up, CAMERA PANS with them and shows the expanse the Bowl below, a packed audience, and the orchestra on t lighted shell. They sit down on the grass. Neff sits near her, not too c It is very dark and they are silhouetted against the shel lights. Neff puts a cigarette in his mouth and strikes a  match. The flame lights up Lola's face. Neff glances at h She is crying. He lights his cigarette and blows out the  match. A pause follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you crying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lola doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a choked voice) Of course I will, Walter. I wouldn't  tell anybody else but you. It's about  Nino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachetti? What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They killed my father together. He  and Phyllis. He helped her do it. I  know he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been following him. He's at her  house, night after night. It was  Phyllis and him all the time. Maybe  he was going with me just for a blind.  And the night of the murder --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised not to talk that way  any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- he was supposed to pick me up  after a lecture at U.C.L.A. -- but  he never showed up. He said he was  sick. Sick! He couldn't show up,  because the train was leaving with  my father on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to cry again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm just crazy. Maybe it's all  just in my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, it's all in your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only wish it was, Walter, because  I still love him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over Neff's face, as he listens to the music, comes the  commentary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachetti. That's funny. Phyllis and  Zachetti. What was he doing up at  her house? I couldn't figure that  one out I tried to make sense out of  it and got nowhere. But the real  brain-twister came the next day. You  sprang it on me, Keyes, after office  hours, when you caught me down in  the lobby of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About 5:00 P.M. or a little later. A stream of office  employees is coming out of an elevator; a second elevator reaches the lobby and some more office employees come out among them Neff, wearing his hat and carrying his briefca CAMERA PRECEDES HIM as he walks toward the entrance doors He is stopped by Keyes' voice, off to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Walter, just a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff stops and looks towards the cigar counter, as he mov towards him. Keyes is standing there buying cigars. He is stuffing them into his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang onto your hat, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing much. The Dietrichson case  just busted wide open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy showed. That's how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The somebody else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. The guy that did it with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's filed suit against us, and  it's okay by me. When we get into  that courtroom I'll tear them apart,  both of them. Come on -- I'll buy  you a martini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With two olives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to get a shave and a  shoeshine. I've got a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie. I still bet she drinks from  the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bites off the end of the cigar and puts the cigar into his mouth. He starts tapping his pockets for a match, as  usual. Neff strikes a match for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They give you matches when they sell  you cigars, Keyes. All you have to  do is ask for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like them. They always explode  in my pockets. So long, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes goes toward the street and OUT OF SCENE. Neff moves back into the lobby, CAMERA FOLLOWING HIM. As he reaches elevator, he looks back over his shoulder, to make sure K is gone, then steps into the empty elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure had me worried, Keyes. I  didn't know if you were playing cat- and-mouse with me, whether you knew  all along I was the somebody else.  That's what I had to find out, and I  thought I knew where to look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To elevator operator) Twelve.

dialogues.speaker: D-14 ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: Neff comes out of the elevator. The receptionist is just  tidying up her desk. She has her hat on and is preparing leave. Neff passes on through the swinging doors to the  twelfth floor balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs, the last of the people  were just leaving.

dialogues.speaker: D-15 12TH FLOOR BALCONY
dialogues.text: Neff enters from the reception room. A couple of belated  employees are leaving for the day. Neff goes toward Keyes office, looks around to make sure he is unobserved, enter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made sure nobody saw me go into  your office.

dialogues.speaker: D-16 KEYES' OFFICE, (DAY)
dialogues.text: Neff has just come in. He goes over to Keyes' desk and  searches the papers on it. He tries the desk drawers and  finds them locked. His eye falls on the dictaphone on the stand beside the desk. A record is on it, the needle is a two-thirds of the way towards the end. He lifts the needl and sets it back to the beginning of the record, sets the switch to playback position. He lifts the arm off the bra and starts the machine. Keyes' voice is heard coming from the horn:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (From Dictaphone) Memo to Mr. Norton. Confidential.  Dietrichson File. With regard to  your proposal to put Walter Neff  under surveillance, I disagree  absolutely. I have investigated his  movements on the night of the crime,  and he is definitely placed in his  apartment from 7:15 P.M. on. In  addition to this, I have known Neff  intimately for eleven years, and I  personally vouch for him, without  reservation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff stops the machine. He sits down slowly, still holdin the horn. He is deeply moved. After a moment, he presses switch again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (From Dictaphone) ...Furthermore, no connection  whatsoever has been established  between Walter Neff and Mrs. Phyllis  Dietrichson, whereas I am now able  to report that such a connection has  been established between her and  another man. This man has been  observed to visit the Dietrichson  home on the night of July 9th, 10th,  11th, 12th and 13th. We have succeeded  in identifying him as one Nino  Zachetti, former medical student,  aged twenty-eight, residing at Lilac  Court Apartments 1228ВЅ N. La Brea  Avenue. We have checked Zachetti's  movements on the night of the crime  and have found that they cannot be  accounted for. I am preparing a more  detailed report for your consideration  and it is my belief that we already  have sufficient evidence against  Zachetti and Mrs. Dietrichson to  justify police action. I strongly  urge that this whole matter be turned  over to the office of the District  Attorney. Respectfully, Barton Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff sits, staring blankly at the wall. The cylinder goes revolving, but no more voice comes -- only the whir of th needle on the empty record. At last he remembers to repla the horn. He hangs it back on its hook. The machine stops Neff gets up from the chair, walks slowly to the door and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: D-17 12TH FLOOR, BALCONY
dialogues.text: Neff has just come out of Keyes' office. He walks slowly  back towards the reception room entrance, then stands the looking out through the glass doors. All the employees ha now left. Neff is entirely alone. He moves as if to go ou then stops rigidly as his face lights up with excitement a sudden idea. He turns quickly and walks on to his own o and enters.

dialogues.speaker: D-18 NEFF'S OFFICE, (DAY)
dialogues.text: Neff walks across to his desk, lifts the telephone and di a number. (During the ensuing telephone conversation, onl what he says is heard. The pauses indicate speeches at th other end of the line).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis? Walter. I've got to see  you... Tonight... Yes, it has to be  tonight... How's eleven o'clock?  Don't worry about Keyes. He's  satisfied... Leave the door on the  latch and put the lights out. No,  nobody's watching the house... I  told you Keyes is satisfied. It's  just for the neighbors... That's  what I said. Yeah. Eleven o'clock.  Goodbye, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff hangs up and stands beside the desk with a grim  expression on his face, takes a handkerchief out and wipe perspiration from his forehead and the palms of his hands The gesture has a symbolic quality, as if he were trying wipe away the murder. Over his face comes the commentary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I don't have to tell you  what I was going to do at eleven  o'clock, Keyes. For the first time I  saw a way to get clear of the whole  mess I was in, and of Phyllis, too,  all at the same time. Yeah, that's  what I thought. But what I didn't  know was that she was all set for  me. That she had outsmarted me again,  just like she always had...

dialogues.speaker: D-19 HALL STAIRWAY OF DIETRICHSON HOME, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: The lights are turned on. Phyllis is coming down the stai She wears white lounging pajamas, and she is carrying  something small and heavy concealed in a scarf in her rig hand. She reaches the front door, opens it slightly, fixe the catch so that the door can be opened from outside. Sh switches off the porch light and the hall light. She move towards the living room, where there is still light on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was all set and waiting for me.  It could have been something in my  voice when I called her up that tipped  her off. And it could have been that  she had the idea already. And an  idea wasn't the only thing she had  waiting for me.

dialogues.speaker: D-20 LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: On the long table behind the davenport, one of the lamps lit. The only other light in the room is a standing lamp  beside the desk. A window toward the back is open, and th it comes the SOUNDS OF MUSIC, probably a neighboring radi Phyllis enters and crosses to the table. She puts out the lamp, then moves over to the desk and puts out the lamp t The room is filled with bright moonlight coming in at the windows. Phyllis crosses to the chair by the fireplace (the one sh sat in the first time Neff came to the house). She lifts loose cushion and puts what was in the scarf behind it. A she withdraws the scarf, there is a brief glint of someth metallic before she covers the hidden object with the cus again. She turns to the low table in front of the davenport and  takes a cigarette from the box. She takes a match and is  about to strike it when, just then, she hears a car comin up the hill. She listens, motionless. The car stops. A ca door is slammed. Calmly, Phyllis strikes the match and lights her cigarett She drops the match casually into a tray, goes back to th chair, sits down and waits, quietly smoking. There are  footsteps outside the house. Over the chair in which Phyllis is sitting, the hallway i visible through the arch. The front door opens. Neff come in, he is silhouetted against the moonlight as he stands  there. He closes the door again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In foreground) In here, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff comes through the arch and walks slowly towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, baby. Anybody else in the  house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A radio up the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff sits down on the arm of the davenport, close to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like the first time I was here.  We were talking about automobile  insurance. Only you were thinking  about murder. And I was thinking  about that anklet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what are you thinking about now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all through thinking. This is  goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye? Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's you that's going, baby. Not me.  I'm getting off the trolley car right  at this corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose you stop being fancy. Let's  have it, whatever it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a friend who's got a funny  theory. He says when two people commit  a murder they're kind of on a trolley  car, and one can't get off without  the other. They're stuck with each  other. They have to go on riding  clear to the end of the line. And  the last stop is the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's got something there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet he has, Two people are going  to ride to the end of the line, all  right. Only I'm not going to be one  of them. I've got another guy to  finish my ride for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you've got it all arranged, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You arranged it for me. I didn't  have to do a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just who are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An acquaintance of yours. A Mr.  Zachetti. Come on, baby, I just got  into this because I knew a little  something about insurance, didn't I?  I was just a sucker. I'd have been  brushed-off as soon as you got your  hands on the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save it. I'm telling this. It's been  you and that Zachetti guy all along,  hasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't make any difference whether  it's true or not. The point is Keyes  believes Zachetti is the guy he's  been looking for. He'll have him in  that gas chamber before he knows  what happened to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's happening to me all this  time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly. What do you expect  to happen to you? You helped him do  the murder, didn't you? That's what  Keyes thinks. And what's good enough  for Keyes is good enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's not good enough for me.  Walter. Maybe I don't go for the  idea. Maybe I'd rather talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes people are where they can't  talk. Under six feet of dirt, for  instance. And if it was you, they'd  just charge it up to Zachetti,  wouldn't they. One more item on his  account. Sure they would. That's  just what they're going to do.  Especially since he's coming here,  tonight... Oh, in about fifteen  minutes from now, baby. With the  cops right behind him. It's all taken  care of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that'd make everything lovely  for you, wouldn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. And it's got to be done before  that suit of yours comes to trial,  and Lola gets a chance to sound off,  and they trip you up on the stand,  and you start to fold up and drag me  down with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Walter. Maybe I had Zachetti  here so they won't get a chance to  trip me up. So we can get that money  and be together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's cute. Say it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came here the first time just to  ask where Lola was. I made him come  back. I was working on him. He's  crazy sort of guy, quick-tempered. I  kept hammering into him that she was  with another man, so he'd get into  one of his jealous rages, and then  I'd tell him where she was. And you  know what he'd have done to her,  don't you, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and for once I believe you.  Because it's just rotten enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're both rotten, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only you're just a little more rotten.  You're rotten clear through. You got  me to take care of your husband, and  then you got Zachetti to take care  of Lola, and maybe take care of me  too, and then somebody else would  have come along to take care of  Zachetti for you. That's the way you  operate isn't it, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose it is, Walter. Is what you've  cooked up for tonight any better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff gets up from the davenport. He listens to the music a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like this music anymore.  It's too close. Do you mind if I  shut the window?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis just stares at him. He goes quietly over to the w and shuts it and draws the curtain. Phyllis speaks to his back:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Her voice low and  urgent) Walter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff turns, something changes in his face. There is the r of a gun. He stands motionless for a moment, then very sl starts towards her. CAMERA IS SHOOTING OVER HIS SHOULDER Phyllis as she stands with the gun in her hand. Neff stop after he has taken a few steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Why don't you  shoot again? Maybe if I came a little  closer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff takes a few more steps towards her and stops again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that. Do you think you can do  it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis is silent. She doesn't shoot. Her expression is  tortured. Neff goes on until he is close to her. Quietly takes the gun out of her unresisting hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you shoot, baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis puts her arms around him in complete surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me it's because you've  been in love with me all this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I never loved you, Walter. Not  you, or anybody else. I'm rotten to  the heart. I used you, just as you  said. That's all you ever meant to  me -- until a minute ago. I didn't  think anything like that could ever  happen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, baby. I'm not buying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not asking you to buy. Just hold  me close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff draws her close to him. She reaches up to his face a kisses him on the lips. As she comes out of the kiss ther is realization in her eyes that this is the final moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the shot the gun explodes once, twice. Phyllis qui in his arms. Her eyes fill with tears. Her head falls lim against his shoulder. Slowly he lifts her and carries her the davenport. He lays her down on it carefully, almost  tenderly. The moonlight coming in at the French doors shi on the anklet. He looks at it for the last time and slowl turns away. As he does so, he puts his hand inside his co and it comes out with blood on it. Only then is it appare that Phyllis' shot actually did hit him. He looks at the  blood on his fingers with a dazed expression and quickly  goes out of the room, the way he came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff comes out of the house. He closes the front door wit his right hand. His left arm hangs limp. He takes a few s down the walk, then suddenly hears somebody approaching. moves behind the palm tree near the walk. A man comes up the steps towards the front door -- Zachet Just as he reaches the door, Neff calls to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey you. Come here a minute. I said  come here, Zachetti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachetti turns and approaches him slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name is Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? And I still don't like it.  What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, kid, I want to give you a  present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes some loose change out of his pocket and holds ou coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a nice new nickel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the gag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose you go back down the hill to  a drug store and make a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff starts to drop the nickel into Zachetti's handkerchi pocket. Zachetti knocks his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your nickel and buy yourself an  ice cream cone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number is Granite 0386. Ask for  Miss Dietrichson. The first name is  Lola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lola? She isn't worth a nickel. And  if I ever talk to her, it's not going  to be over any telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough, aren't you? Take the nickel.  Take it and call her. She wants you  to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? She doesn't want any part of  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who told you that, and it's  not true. She's in love with you.  Always has been. Don't ask me why. I  couldn't even guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachetti just stares at him. Neff moves again to put the  nickel into Zachetti's pocket. This time Zachetti allows to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now beat it. Granite 0386, I told  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He motions toward the street below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachetti goes slowly past him. Neff grabs him and pushes almost violently down the walk. Zachetti goes out of shot The sound of his steps dies away as Neff looks after him. Then, far off in the distance, the SIREN OF A POLICE CAR heard. Neff moves off through the shrubbery toward the side of t house where he parked his car.

dialogues.speaker: D-22 NEFF'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The desk lamp is still lighted. Outside the windows, the  dawn is slowly breaking. Neff is still clutching the horn of the dictaphone. There are eight or nine used cylinders on the desk beside him. widening stain of blood shows on the left shoulder of his gray jacket. He is very weak by now, and his voice holds note of utter exhaustion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost four-thirty now, Keyes.  It's cold. I wonder if she's still  lying there alone in that house, or  whether they've found her by now. I  wonder a lot of things, but they  don't matter any more, except I want  to ask you to do me a favor. I want  you to be the one to tell Lola, kind  of gently, before it breaks wide  open... Yes, and I'd like you to  look after her and that guy Zachetti,  so he doesn't get pushed around too  much. Because...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly he stops his dictation with an instinctive feeli that he is not alone in the room. As he turns in his chair the CAMERA PULLS BACK slowly. Th office door is wide open. Keyes is standing a few steps i it. Behind him, on the balcony outside, stands the night  watchman and the colored janitor, peering curiously into room over Keyes' shoulder. Slowly, and without taking his eyes off Neff's face, Keye reaches back and pushes the door shut. Neff hangs up the dictaphone horn. He looks at Keyes with faint, tired grin and speaks very slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes moves towards him a few steps and stands without  answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up pretty early, aren't you? I always  wondered what time you got down to  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keyes, staring at him, still does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or did your little man pull you out  of bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The janitor did. Seems you leaked a  little blood on the way in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff makes a motion indicating the used cylinders standin on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to straighten out that  Dietrichson story for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I gather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been standing there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of a crazy story with a crazy  twist to it. One you didn't quite  figure out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't figure them all, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. You can't, can you?  And now I suppose I get the big  speech, the one with all the two- dollar words in it. Let's have it,  Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all washed up, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Keyes. That was short anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at each other for a long moment, then, with in effort Neff gets up on his feet and stands there swaying little. His face is covered with sweat. His shoulder is  bleeding. He is on the verge of collapse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, I'm going to call a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Bitterly) What for? So they can patch me up?  So they can nurse me along till I'm  back on my feet? So I can walk under  my own power into that gas chamber  up in San Quentin? Is that it, Keyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got a different idea.  Look here. Suppose you went back to  bed and didn't find these cylinders  till tomorrow morning, when the office  opens. From then on you can play it  any way you like. Would you do that  much for me, Keyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me one good reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need four hours to get where I'm  going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going anywhere, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet I am. I'm going across the  border.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't got a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good enough to try for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never make the border.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you think. Watch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff starts to move towards the door, staggering a little holding himself upright with great effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a voice of stony  calm) You'll never even make the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff has reached the door. He twists the knob and drags t door open. He turns in it to look back at Keyes' implacab face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, Keyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff goes out, leaving the door wide open. THE CAMERA FOL his staggering walk along the BALCONY TOWARDS THE ELEVATO LOBBY. The sound of his breathing is so harsh and loud th for a moment it dominates the scene. Finally he reaches t swing doors leading into the lobby and starts to push the open. At this moment he collapses. He clutches the edge o the door and as it swings around with him he falls to the floor. He tries to struggle up but cannot rise. In background comes the sound of a telephone being dialed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... Send an ambulance to the  Pacific Building on Olive Street...  Yeah... It's a police job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the sound of the phone being replaced in its cra Then there are footsteps growing louder along the balcony and Keyes walks slowly into the shot. He kneels down besi Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doing, Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff manages a faint smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Only somebody moved the  elevator a couple of miles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Slowly and with great  difficulty) You know why you didn't figure this  one, Keyes? Let me tell you. The guy  you were looking for was too close.  He was right across the desk from  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer than that, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyes of the two men meet in a moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff fumbles for the handkerchief in Keyes' pocket, pulls out and clumsily wipes his face with it. The handkerchief drops from his hand. He gets a loose cigarette out of his pocket and puts it between his lips. Then with great  difficulty he gets out a match, tries to strike it, but i too weak. Keyes takes the match out of his hand, strikes for him and lights his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following pages are for an alternate ending that dire Billy Wilder actually shot but later decided against.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Slowly and with great  difficulty) You know why you didn't figure this  one, Keyes? Let me tell you. The guy  you were looking for was too close.  He was right across the desk from  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer than that, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyes of the two men meet in a moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff fumbles for the handkerchief in Keyes' pocket, pulls out and clumsily wipes his face with it. Then, clutching handkerchief against his shoulder, he speaks to Keyes for the last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of that... trolley line...  just as I get off... you be there...  to say goodbye... will you, Keyes?

dialogues.speaker: E-1 WITNESS ROOM IN DEATH CHAMBER
dialogues.text: Showing the witness room and approximately one-half of th gas chamber. BOOM SHOT towards guard standing BACK TO CAM at entrance door. Except for this guard the room is empty Guard opens the door. Two other guards enter, followed by group of witnesses and newspaper men, each of whom remove his hat as he enters the room. They form a group around t outside of the gas chamber, some looking in through the g windows, some standing in the background on low platforms against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAMERA SLOWLY BEGINS TO MOVE IN AND DOWN, AND CENTERS
dialogues.text: Keyes, as he enters the room and stands behind the door. face is seen through the bars of the door, which is then  closed, and CAMERA MOVES TO A CLOSEUP. His eyes follow th action of the closing door, then slowly look towards the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: E-2 THE GAS CHAMBER, EMPTY
dialogues.text: On its windows show reflections of the spectators, includ the face of Keyes. The door to the gas chamber opens in the background, and  beyond that another door opens. Neff comes in between two guards. He is wearing a white open-necked shirt, blue den pants, and walks barefooted on a cocoanut matting. He mov into the gas chamber, looks through the windows in the  direction of Keyes and nods quickly, recognizing him. The guards turn him around and seat him in one of the two met chairs, with his back to the witnesses. They strap his ar legs and body to the chair. The guards go out.

dialogues.speaker: E-3 THE DOOR TO THE GAS CHAMBER
dialogues.text: It is open. The three guards come out of the gas chamber  into the ante-chamber, where stand the warden, executione two doctors, the minister and the acid man, and possibly  several guards. The executioner and one guard close the door. The guard s the big wheel which tightens it. The wheel at first turns very quickly, then, as it tightens, the guard uses  considerable force to seal the chamber tight. The guard s out of the shot. The gas chamber is now sealed.

dialogues.speaker: E-4 THE WITNESSES AND KEYES
dialogues.text: They are intently watching Neff in the gas chamber.

dialogues.speaker: E-5 THE ANTE-CHAMBER
dialogues.text: The warden looks slowly around the room, sees that everyo is in his proper place and that the stethoscope, which on doctor holds, is connected with the outlet in the wall of the gas chamber. Also that the man in charge of the acid ready. The warden makes a motion to the acid man. The aci man releases the mixed acid into a pipe connecting with a countersunk receptacle under Neff's chair. (This action i only suggested). The warden looks at the clock, then turn to the executioner and nods.

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTIONER
dialogues.text: He pushes a metal lever. (This immerses the pellets of cy in the acid under the chair.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA IS SHOOTING ABOVE Neff's head (just out of shot),  towards spectators standing outside the gas chamber, Keye in the center. Gas floats up into scene between CAMERA an spectators. Keyes, unable to watch, looks away.

dialogues.speaker: E-8 THE FIRST DOCTOR
dialogues.text: as he listens on stethoscope connected with the gas chamb He glances at the clock above his head.

dialogues.speaker: E-9 THE SECOND DOCTOR
dialogues.text: He stands to right of the gas chamber door, taking notes a pad. He glances towards First Doctor (out of scene) and looks through venetian blinds into the gas chamber. The a man stands near him.

dialogues.speaker: E-10 THE FIRST DOCTOR
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTING FROM HIGH ANGLE TOWARDS HIM as he listens stethoscope. The doctor glances at the clock again. He ta his stethoscope from his ears. He nods to the warden, Thi indicates that the man is dead. CAMERA PANS with warden a he turns to open the door connecting the ante-chamber wit the witness room.

dialogues.speaker: WITNESSES GROUPED AROUND GAS CHAMBER
dialogues.text: The door connecting with the ante-chamber opens. A guard  comes through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all, gentlemen, Vacate the  chamber, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard withdraws and closes the door by which he enter The witnesses slowly start to file out. A guard has opene the outer door. The witnesses put their hats on as they p through. A few go close to the windows of the gas chamber look in at the dead man before they leave. All the witnesses have now left, except Keyes, who stands shocked and tragic, beyond the door. The guard goes to hi and touches his arm, indicating to him that he must leave Keyes glances for the last time towards the gas chamber a slowly moves to go out.

dialogues.speaker: E-12 CORRIDOR OUTSIDE THE DEATH CHAMBER
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTING IN THROUGH THE OPEN DOOR AT KEYES, who is just turning to leave. Keyes comes slowly out into the da narrow corridor. His hat is on his head now, his overcoat pulled around him loosely. He walks like an old man. He t eight or ten steps, then mechanically reaches a cigar out his vest pocket and puts it in his mouth. His hands, in t now familiar gesture, begin to pat his pockets for matche Suddenly he stops, with a look of horror on his face. He  stands rigid, pressing a hand against his heart. He takes the cigar out of his mouth and goes slowly on towards the door, CAMERA PANNING with him. When he has almost reached the door, the guard stationed there throws it wide, and a blaze of sunlight comes in from the prison yard outside. Keyes slowly walks out into the sunshine. stiffly, his he bent, a forlorn and lonely man.
